text: My boy brought this to me a couple days ago, asking if I'd read it to him.I did, and it's quickly become a new favorite.It's not terribly complex, or long, or ethically enriching. But then again, not all books need to be. What this book does have is a marvelously tight and deceptively effortless rhyme and meter. I say "deceptively" here because I know that sort of thing doesn't come easily. Despite the fact that the book is wonderful fun to read, I know the author sweat blood making the language work out right.Good book. Fun to read out loud. Holds up under multiple readings. Absolutely worth your time.

Julia Donaldson’s stories never fail to delight, and this picture book of The Gruffalo is one of the very best. First published in 1999, the scary gruffalo has become one of the world’s best-loved monsters, starring in films and shows galore, and inspiring a huge amount of merchandise. This is the original picture book which started it all, and which has itself won many awards, been translated into over fifty languages, and has been voted the UK’s favourite bedtime story.It begins with a simple idea, of a little brown mouse taking a walk in a “deep dark wood”. We see a lovely illustration of the deep dark wood before the story begins … and the small child I read it to thought he might just be able to spy something sinister behind the trees, although he didn’t know the story at all … So we begin:“A mouse took a stroll through the deep dark wood.A fox saw the mouse and the mouse looked good.‘Where are you going to, little brown mouse?Come and have lunch in my underground house.’” Oh my, what a crafty expression there is on the face of the fox! But our perky, brave little mouse is very quick-thinking:“It’s terribly kind of you, Fox, but no –I’m going to have lunch with a gruffalo!”And as he describes the tusks, teeth and jaws of the terrible monster to the fox, he finishes with:“and his favourite food is roasted fox”whereupon the fox’s eyes get very wide indeed, and he scoots off in a panic. The mouse however, calmly carries on on his way. In time he meets several other dangerous animals; a fox, an owl, and a snake. Each one whom he meets, clearly intends to eat the mouse, and invites him back to their home, ostensibly for a meal. But every time, the mouse claims he is expected by the fierce gruffalo to his house for a meal instead. We might also have felt as apprehensive and scared as the animals who want to eat the mouse. We learn for instance, that the gruffalo’s favourite foods are “owl ice cream”, and “scrambled snake”. But in fact we don’t feel frightened, and we don’t even believe him! My little friend was giggling as much as I was, because:“Silly old fox, doesn’t he know?There’s no such thing as a gruffalo!”“Silly old owl, doesn’t he know?There’s no such thing as a gruffalo!”And:“Silly old snake, doesn’t he know?There’s no such thing as a gruffalo!”We both had huge grins on our faces, until I turned the next page. Oh! There he was! As large as life and twice as ugly:“Oh help! Oh no! It’s a gruffalo!”And we clearly see a real, live, gruffalo! He seems to be half a grizzly bear and half a buffalo. And when he spots the mouse:“‘My favourite food’ the gruffalo said,‘You’ll taste good on a slice of bread!’”But once again the mouse uses his quick wits and cunning. He boasts to the gruffalo that he, the mouse, is the scariest animal in the forest, and what’s more, he can prove it! The gruffalo is very doubtful of this, but humours the mouse, and accompanies him through the forest. Then the two of them once again encounter all the animals the mouse had met before. Not surprisingly, each creature is terrified by the sight of the mouse’s great “friend”, the gruffalo, whom he had described so perfectly earlier. Each one runs off in a panic, and gradually the gruffalo becomes more and more impressed with the mouse’s apparent toughness. When the mouse then claims that his favourite food is “gruffalo crumble”, it is the gruffalo who turns tail (quite literally, in his case) and flees, with a very very scared expression on his face. Then, in the final double spread:“All was quiet in the deep dark wood. The mouse found a nut and the nut was good.”The Gruffalo is a perfectly structured story, inviting the reader equally to laugh and have mock terror. Even the tiniest of tots love to be “frightened” in this way. Julia Donaldson seems to understand children completely, from the inside. She says that this story was inspired by a Chinese tale about a clever girl who tricks a hungry tiger into believing she is the Queen of the Jungle and scares him away. Julia Donaldson knew that this would make a great picture book for children between about three and seven years of age, but she wanted to do it in rhyme. She couldn’t think of anything to rhyme with “tiger”, so she created her own monster ending in “O”, to rhyme with “doesn’t he know?” She uses rhyming couplets, and includes much repetitive verse with just minor amusing tweaks, which delight the listener. We know what is coming, but each time there is a little thrill of surprise to make us laugh. The book is about 700 words long, and much of its charm also lies in the illustrations by Axel Scheffler. Once you’ve read it, it is impossible to imagine the gruffalo as anything else, but in fact he might have looked very different. “Our” monster is scary in a cute, dim-witted sort of way, but apparently Axel Scheffler’s first designs were of a monster who was far more frightening than the one we know. He also wondered about making the animals wear clothes, but in the end decided against it.My little Turkish neighbour, aged just four, and I both giggled (and one of us squealed a bit) at this delightful picture book. We haven’t yet ventured through our local “deep dark woods” though. Perhaps we should do that before we read the follow-up story, written five years later and called, The Gruffalo’s Child. After all, how terrifying might that one be?

Brains beat brawns every time. The Gruffalo teaches children to be patient and understanding. Whilst not necessarily advocating the cunning manipulation that the mouse utilises, it does suggest that there is more to people than their outward appearance. Just because someone may appear “scary” doesn’t mean they’re a bad person, and innocent seeming things can be the worse. Judge only on actions not how one appears.

One of the delights of parenthood is being able to enjoy some of the most popular children's books from the last 20 years, The Gruffalo is an award winning hit from 1999.It's a brilliant simple rhythmic story as a mouse trys to scare off other woodland creatures from eating him by describing this big beast known as The Gruffalo.Unfortunately The Mouse is about to discover that he's been right all along!I think the reason why this appeals so much as it hooks into a child's vivid imagination, I remember tells of strange creatures living in the woods when I used to go camping.With each animal mouse meets the descriptions become even more elaborate!This is one that I'm looking forward to enjoying together over and over again.

I love, love, love this book. I'm a fan of stories where a little mousy guy gets its way against the most terrible odds, and this one it's just perfect in that and many other ways.The little mouse, our protagonist, is smart and full of grit but he's also lucky and sweet and it's so cool to see him getting out of a bad situation just to run into a worst one to then manage to get out of that as well.The illustrations are lovely, the rhymes are funny, the story it's interesting--as shown by my niece's little yelps of excitement each time a new nemesis appears--so I can't recommend this book enough.Read it with your children before bed, read it to yourself after a long day... just read it and enojy, it doesn't matter when.

Foxes are supposed to be cunning, but it is the mouse who is cunning and manipulative. He or She manipulated all the predators fears against them to stay safe. That's pretty smart. I guess that's how you survive. I love that even the Gruffalo had fears. I guess being a mouse, the mouse has had to learn to live with fear. It's an amazing story about bravery and finding the weakness of scary looking, bigger obstacles in life. Find that fear and use it against you. Does the mouse offer a seminar? I need to learn a thing or two from it.The kids enjoyed this. The nephew loved the gruffalo and the niece did too for different reasons. They both gave it 4 stars.
A wonderful tale and movie about dealing with bullies. A must for kids!

The Gruffalo, by Julia Donaldson is a cute rhyming story about a mouse and a gruffalo. We loved the combination of the sly little mouse and gullible gruffalo. 
 "My favorite food!" the gruffalo said."You'll taste good on a slice of bread!""Good?" said the mouse. "Don't call me good!I'm the scariest creature in this deep dark wood.Just walk behind me and soon you'll see,everyone is afraid of me."
The illustrations are detailed and interesting. Overall, its a charming little story children will enjoy.4****

Another delightful rhyming story from the pen of Julia Donaldson with brilliant accompanying illustrations by Axel Scheffler.Donaldson and Scheffler are a formidable team (although not quite rivalling that of Dahl and Blake) and this is undoubtedly one of their classics. The Gruffalo is a great character and creation loved by adults and children alike. Although well adapted for television and stage versions - nothing can compare to the original story and illustrations.

With Julia Donaldson's 1999 picture book (and in my opinion already a classic) The Gruffalo, aside from the author's sweetly and humorously (not to mention rhythmically rollicking and yes just asking to be read aloud) poetic text and Axel Scheffler's delightful and visually stunning accompanying illustrations (which are not only wonderfully colourfully expressive and as such a perfect mirror to and for Donaldson's engaging verses, especially how Axel Scheffler has drawn the little mouse main protagonist, it sweetly and nostalgically reminds me visually of one of my very favourite German cartoons from when I was a young child, namely Die Sendung mit der Maus), for me The Gruffalo as a unit is actually not just a fun and engaging picture book romp. For indeed, The Gruffalo also shows both with Julia Donaldson's verses and Axel Scheffler's accompanying artwork the importance and even the at times necessity of both bravery and cleverness when dealing with possible dangers, bullies, nasties and monsters, as the little mouse bravely ventures into the forest and cleverly keeps itself safe from potential predators by telling a fantastical tale of the forest monster known as the Gruffalo (and later, when the Gruffalo actually turns out to not be a fantastical imaginary beast after all, but a very real and bona fide monster, how the mouse, instead of simply being frightened and capitulating then makes the Gruffalo actually believe that it, that the little mouse is in fact a big, bad and frightening animal, bravely manipulating both the Gruffalo and the forest animals to keep its diminutive self safe from harm, from being consumed as a meal or a snack).

Delightful!I've heard of this book, and my kids have seen the cartoon on Netflix, yet we hadn't read the book until recently, when my sister gave it to my youngest. We love Donaldson's Room on the Broom, and this is more of the same. Tight, elegant rhymes, a fun story, and great pictures. Now we need The Gruffalo's Child!

This book tells the tale of a scary Gruffalo,is he real, is he pretend, nobody knows.A sly little mouse describes him so true, other animals listen intently, their ears fixed like glue.Through the deep dark woods does little mouse go,announcing his meeting with the fierce gruffalo.His aim is to put off predators leering in the woods,who all want to eat little mouse, they surely would.A fox comes along, thinking of his meal for the day, little mouse is quick to react, as he starts to say, "Those terrible tusks, and terrible toes, with terrible teeth in his terrible jaws.He has knobbly knees and turn out toes, and a poisonous wart at the end of his nose. His eyes are orange, his tongue is black,he has purple prickles all over his back!" Little mouse uses his tricks to leer off owl and snake,proud of himself for thinking he’s invented a fake!Through the woods little mouse continues to go,unaware that round the corner stands the big Grufallo!As little mouse sees him, heartbeats he can feel,The Grufallo isn’t pretend, he is in fact real!Little mouse continues his tricks and uses the beast, to scare off the animals who wanted him for their feast. Little mouse sat alone, amazed at his luck,as he nibbles into a brown, delicious sweet nut.

Description: This is a rhyming story of a mouse and a monster. Little mouse goes for a walk in a dangerous forest. To scare off his enemies he invents tales of a fantastical creature called the Gruffalo. So imagine his surprise when he meets the real Gruffalo.4* The Stick Man5* The Gruffalo

This is a totally awesome book. My children read it at school and they really loved it. And of course we bought the book and we saw the movie.And then we read the book again again and again :-)It is a clever story about a little mouse and a scary (not really) monster, the Gruffalo. The intelligent sourceful little mouse manipulated the bigger animals who wanted to eat him. He made them think that he is scarier than Gruffalo. Thus, he should not be eaten.The little mouse though that Gruffalo is a made up monster, but he was wrong. Surprise!
Have just bought this and all the toys to go with it for my little nephew. Hope he's going to like it as much as I did!
Great story! You can watch Michelle Obama reading The Gruffalo here and then add it to your reading challenge: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wyhgu...
Ha ha ha. It was really great. this is my new favorite children’s book. :D
This is a wonderful book for kids! I loved the illustrations, and the story is so smart. Would make a great gift or a nice first book to someone who's just learning how to read.

Popular kids books are powerful vehicles of merchandise. Take The Hungry Caterpillar (as just one example) - you can buy the book, the cardboard book, the cloth book, the colouring book, the pop-up book, the touch-and-feel book, the finger-puppet book, the audio book, the baby 'development toy', the plushy toy, the 'big apple' toy, the play floor tiles, the bedspread, the toothbrush, the body-wash, the bubble-bath, the playroom stickers, the height chart, the calendar, the garden water toy, the memory game, the seat-belt strap covers, the baby vests, the kids t-shirts, the welly-boots, the backpack, the lunchbox, the pencil case... that's just off the top of my head - I'm sure there's more!I remember that book from my own childhood, and I don't find this grating - it's sweet, it's unisex, the art style is lush and I don't mind seeing it splashed around.But I was 15 when 
The Gruffalo
 was published... listening to Rage Against The Machine and lamenting the over-commercialised tat we peddle to our children... To my teenage self, 
The Gruffalo
 was just another hook to get parents buying their kids more crap: a symbol of a broken system. Obviously, I never read it - but I was aware there was a TV adaptation made (with much fanfare) and a sequel book, etc. 
The Gruffalo
 has become a 'standard' (one of those books every kid should have...) and I was surprised to find how much I liked it!The rhythm and rhyme is perfect - it's heavily structured, but flows naturally, so even the most stilted beadtime-story reader is guided smoothly into a sing-song cadence. The story itself is clever and fun. The art style is very modern and clean - a touch generic for me (which is why it doesn't get 5 stars) - but overall 
The Gruffalo
 is a great bedtime story, and certainly one of Fin's favourites. We have the paperback and the noisy-hardback - the one where you press the buttons for Gruffalo's growl, or Owl's hoot, etc. We also have a Gruffalo flannel... but aside from that we've avoided any more of the merch!We also have many of Donaldson & Scheffler's other books - and I'm pleased to say that they're consistently good. The Gruffalo's Child, Room on the Broom, The Smartest Giant in Town, A Squash and a Squeeze, Charlie Cook's Favourite Book, and Superworm all have my little boy's seal of approval. After this I read: The Gruffalo's Child

I hadn't read this book since my childhood, loved it!Great opportunities to look at rhyme and rhythm with children. The repetitive line of 'there's no such thing as Gruffalo' would be lovely for EAL children to join in too. You could also explore Donaldson's use of alliteration with children. Children could create more animals for the mouse to meet and their own rhymes for them. In science, children could look at the different habitats in which the animals live in. Good morals about not having to be the biggest to be the best. That you shouldn't judge from what you see, as the Gruffalo wasn't scary. Also not to believe everything you hear.

Despite the lead character a rather scary looking monster, this is a fun bedtime read geared at younger children. The story is told through rhyme, as we meet various animals who cross paths with the giant Gruffalo. With beautifully unique illustrations, this is a perfect gift for young readers.

The Gruffalo, by Julia Donaldson The Gruffalo is about a cheeky and confident little mouse who defends himself from an array of predators, whilst walking through ‘a deep dark wood’. He defends himself through words rather than violence. He does this by outsmarting the naïve predators by claiming that he is about to meet a ‘Gruffalo’, a mythical beast. The mouse frightens the predators by giving them vivid descriptions of the beast - ironically, the mouse does meet the 'Gruffalo', and outwits him too.  Overall, this is a very enjoyable children’s tale with an exciting setting and great introductions to various characters. The various animal characters help children identify with different types of animals that could be in a forest. The use of ‘deep dark wood’ to describe the forest works very well, as it sets the scene and makes the reader excited about what there is to come. The dialogue between characters is very clever and the rhyming is well done. It creates a rhythm for the story and makes you want to read on. The descriptions of the 'Gruffalo' stimulates one’s imagination and the concept of meeting the 'Gruffalo' becomes very exciting. The illustrations are fantastic and capture the essence of the story. The consistent story works very well, especially with an anti-climatic ending where the mouse remains superior. Every part of the story is great, but the witty and clever character of the mouse is definitely the main highlight. I would say that this book is aimed at 3 to 6 year olds and can also be enjoyed by older children. The story could be used in the classroom by interacting with the visuals of the book. The teacher can ask questions about what the animals are called or if the children can spot the ‘Gruffalo’ anywhere in the detailed illustrations of the ‘deep dark wood’. The repetition and rhyming theme of the book would make it very enjoyable for children and would help them understand what could happen next in the story. This story could support a lesson in literacy and a topic of rhyming poems and using rhyme in creative writing and story telling.

I first came across the Gruffalo when BBC3 pretty much kept it on replay. I then decided to buy the book for my niece and found that its far far better in comparison to the film version. What enhanced the qualities of the book even more was the fact that it had sounds! This meant that my niece could not only listen to me read, but join in by associating the correct sound with the right animal. The book is very bright with lovely illustrations thus making it even more appealing (even without having read the words yet). The story revolves predominately around a mouse and his trek through the woods. He bumps into some intimidating animals and realises that his imagination (of a made up ‘monster’) will serve him well. Unbeknown to the little mouse, this fictional monster does exist! But true to form, the little mouse manages to conjure up a plan that will aide his survival back through the woods. A great story for children to re-enact and create a colourful wall display. I love how this book can be read over and over, yet the excitement remains!!

Julia Donaldson does an excellent job on writing this creative story book. The first time I read the story, I initially felt it was a very long read for children as I thought it was long myself and repetitive but upon reading it a second, third time, I realised I had not fully appreciated how good the storybook was. Complete with rhyme and repitition it captured my attention and the children to whom I was reading to. The use of animals was a good idea as children were able to point out different animals that they came accross throughout the book, creating a sense of excitement. Use of synonyms such as 'Big and little' help children to begin to understand opposites of words, a good literacy aspect of children's learning. Ideally, the book is for 3-7 year olds, but is enjoyed by many, a good must have within any home or classroom.

I wish I had a dollar for every time I've read this book because my 2 year old cannot get enough of it. It was a gift for her 2nd birthday and hardly a day has gone by since that we've not read it to her. It's a bit long so initially Kidlet would flip through the pages before I could finish reading it, but after four months, she sits through it and waits for her favorite parts. She even learned the cadence of the words, so when she asks for it we recognize more the rhythm than the actual words she says. It's a clever book and I have come to really enjoy it. Kidlet juts out her "knobbly knees, turned out toes," and nose for me to tap when I get to those parts of the story, and she loves when I tickle her back with "purple prickles."

The Gruffalo is another thoroughly enjoyable book by Donaldson and Scheffler, with wonderful illustrations. There is good a use of rhymes, descriptive vocabulary and repetition throughout the story which gives it a nice flow and makes you want to read on. The Gruffalo is a humorous story to read out loud during story time. It could be used in Reception and Year 1 Art sessions with English and Literacy where the children can create their own monsters and write a description for each body part, just like in the book.

In the big dark woods, a mouse is going for a walk when he meets a fox that, thinking the mouse looks like a good meal, tries to lure him back to his den. The mouse is an intelligent little thing, and explains to the fox that he can't come because he's having lunch with a gruffalo. The fox has never heard of a gruffalo before, so the mouse starts to describe a terrible monster who likes to eat roasted fox. The fox, terrified, runs away. The mouse is molested by an owl next, and then a snake, and each time he tricks the animals into thinking there's a bigger, badder beast in the woods than they.Until the mouse meets an actual gruffalo, just as he described it, and the gruffalo wants to eat him too. But he's still got some tricks up his sleeve, does mouse!This is an absolutely wonderful story that I've read to my 2 month old baby several times already - he has no idea what's going on of course but the pictures grab his attention and I can do silly voices that make him grin and squeal; the word "gruffalo" seems to delight him and the cadence of the rhyming text does too. I can't wait till he's older and can actually enjoy the story of the clever little mouse who outwits the bigger, stronger animals of the woods - great lesson in that, but also lots of fun!

The Gruffalo is a classic children’s read with a beautifully written story and wonderful illustrations about a little mouse who takes a journey into the woods. On his way he encounters a fox, an owl and a snake who all want to eat the little mouse, until he tells them he is expecting a visit from the Gruffalo! “He has terrible tusks and terrible claws and terrible teeth and terrible jaws”. The little mouse ends up finding the Gruffalo and manages to convince the giant that all the animals are afraid of him! A humorous return through the forest follows. I feel this book will engage young children and early readers as it allows them to get into the character of the Gruffalo, which provides a fantastic opportunity for role play and describing the features of the Gruffalo. The story is a wonderful read for children and you can’t help but keep looking at the beautiful illustrations which bring the story to life. A must read for all children.
This is my Lamby's (5) favourite book ever! She giggles all the way through.

Haha I just really wanted to tell everyone that this is my favorite kids’ book for the toddler age. The rhythm, cadence and rhymes are perfect. I memorized it quickly (the mark, to me, of an excellent kid’s book: it’s simple and the lines are intuitive). The little brown mouse is fun, funny, and delightful.

The Gruffalo is a children’s book by author Julia Donaldson. It tells the story of a mouse’s walk in the woods. On his walk the mouse encounters any dangerous animals such as a snake, a fox and an owl. Each animal he meets invites them back to their house where they clearly intend to eat him. The mouse is very cunning and he declines each animals invitation by telling them that he is going for dinner at his friend, the Gruffalo’s house. He tells each animal that they are the Gruffalo’s favourite food and describes his frightening features to them. This allows the mouse to continue safely on his walk through the forest. The story then turns when the mouse meets a real Gruffalo. He tells the Gruffalo that he is the most fearsome animal in the forest and shows him by walking back through the forest where all the earlier animals run in fear away. This in turn scares the Gruffalo away from the mouse. This is one of the most popular children’s books around. The humour in it and the easy to follow story with the rhymes make it a much loved book for children. It can be easily used to tell a class story which can be then transformed into roleplay, hot seating etc.

This book is about a mouse who took a stroll into the woods, along his way he scares a fox, an owl and a snake by telling them the story of the gruffalo who eats them for dinner. The mouse then runs into the gruffalo and he is hungry for mice. The mouse advised the gruffalo that everyone is afraid of him and that the gruffalo should be scared. To prove himself he advised the gruffalo to follow him behind, as they walk through the woods they come across the fox, the owl and the snake who run away when they see the gruffalo although the gruffalo believes they are running from the mouse as he is the most scariest creature in the woods.I enjoyed this book, especially reading it to my reception class. The author had put in some sentences to rhyme and also repeating pattern of phrases. Great illustration and very captivating. Book gives humour especially the part when the mouse persuades the gruffalo that all the other creatures are running from him when really they are scared of the gruffalo.This book is fantastic for story time and I recommend for reception and Year 1.

I really enjoyed reading this beautifully illustrated story, in which a small mouse escapes the clutches of woodland creatures Fox, Owl and Snake by outsmarting them his imagination and creativity (a classic case of how brain can overcome brawn).Mouse creates the story of a hideous and fierce 'Gruffalo' unawares to him that such creature actually exists, ‘Silly old snake doesn't he know there is no such thing as a Gruffalo'. On encountering the hideous creature himself, Mouse successfully convinces the Gruffalo that he, Mouse, is the scariest creature around!I found this story quite humorous in places, and found that it's rhyming verses and repetition was ideal to allow children to easily join in. Having educational elements within the story I'd say that this book is suitable for young children. However, having read and enjoyed the book so much myself, it's clear this story is suitable for all ages.

While staying at home during this pandemic, I read about Michelle Obama’s online story times. Curious, I tuned in to her presentation of The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson. I wasn’t disappointed!It was a joy to listen to her reading this wonderful children’s story about a little mouse who cleverly outwits a fox, an owl, and a snake who all would like to eat him! Told in rhyme, this book is perfect to read aloud to young children.

Ah The Gruffalo, you were always there in my childhood when I needed you. Whilst The Gruffalo does not win first place in my childhood reads, it is certainly high up there (within my top ten, which is a hard thing to do considering the number of childhood reads out there).Charming and loveable it is certainly a book to keep the wee ones happy.

The rhyming is excellent, fun to read and the story is good. The drawings aren't beautiful but they have lots of interesting little insects and things to catch the attention of a small reader. My little one (nearly two) listens with anticipation until the Gruffalo appears .... Oh! excited face! And then closes the book. Gruffalo has arrived, the end. Maybe one day I'll get to keep reading.

I really enjoy reading this book to my daughter and she loves looking at the stunning illustrations. It always ends up taking a long time to read this as there are usually a million questions about what is going on in the pictures.

We love the Gruffalo! We've watched the BBC claymation movie on Netflix and wanted a copy of the book. My friend and her kids had an extra one they let us have. Our favorite line is, of course, "Silly _____, doesn't he know? There's no such thing as a Gruffalo!"
I understand why this book has gotten much praise. Very catchy and i love the cunning mouse
Hands down the best childrens book - I loved reading it to my son as well as the other books by her. He's getting older now so I cant read it as much :(
A tiny mouse uses his wits to avoid becoming someone's lunch and in doing so, becomes king of the deep, dark forest. ADORABLE!
Published some time ago but still a family favourite. Suitable for children of all ages both big or small. Recommended.

This is classic children’s book. A very clever mouse takes a stroll through the deep dark woods and encounters a series of animals, from a fox, to an owl to a snake, who all want to eat him. He frightens them by telling them that he’s on his way to meet a Gruffalo that has terrible tusks, terrible claws, terrible claws and terrible jaws. They all get scared and run away. Then all of a sudden, when the mouse is strolling in the woods, he comes face to face with the Gruffalo and he also wants to eat him up. So the mouse says” I’m the scariest creature in the wood.” “Everyone is afraid of me.” When the Gruffalo hears this, he bursts with laughter. Then the mouse takes the Gruffalo to the snake, the owl and the fox. They all see the Gruffalo and disappear as quickly as they can. In the end, the mouse scares and fools the Gruffalo and says “Everyone is afraid of me”. Gruffalo sees this and as quick as the wind the Gruffalo turns and flees away.The book is fun to read as it has short rhymes and great illustrations by Alex Scheffler.I recommend this book for EYFS and Key Stage 1 children.You can do many things such as:• The story can be used effectively as part circle time and then discussed amongst children in EYFS and KS1. • You can have a lesson on the characters, settings and endings.• To check understanding of the story, you can ask children questions such as: What is the name of this book?Name the characters of the story.Describe the mouse’s character.Which animal does the mouse meet at the beginning of the story?Why does the fox run away?Which animal does the mouse meet after the fox?Why does the owl fly away?Which animal does the mouse meet after the owl?Why does the snake slither away?Why do all the animals want to eat the mouse?After the snake, who does the mouse see in the woods?Describe the Gruffalo.Does the Gruffalo want to eat the mouse?Which animal sees the Gruffalo first?Which animal sees the Gruffalo second?Which animal sees the Gruffalo third?What does mouse do at the end of the story?• During Art the children can make Gruffalo, fox, snake and owl masks.• Hot seating – Asking the children how the mouse felt when he saw all the animals or how the animals felt when the mouse tried to scare them. During this session, children can wear character masks and make sounds of animals.• Another activity can be to match the rhyming words together.• Role playing can use the masks to retell the story. • You can also go onto a brilliant website that has lots of games and activities. www.gruffalo.com/section.php?s=html/g...

Such a simple but brilliantly executed story about a mouse and a monster. One that you can read again and again without getting tired of it. Time now to watch the short animated film =)5 out of 5 stars!EDIT: Still enjoy picking this up on a regular basis.
No matter how small you are, with a little bit of smarts, you can stand up to fierce creatures

Blimey, not only do we have great illustrations once more by Axel Scheffler but we also have six 12-piece jigsaws to do after reading the story!A little mouse takes a stroll in the deep dark wood with the intention of having lunch with a Gruffalo.He meets Fox who doesn't know what a Gruffalo is so Mouse describes him and tells Fox that the Gruffalo's favourite meal is roasted fox. Fox quickly dashes off!Mouse then meets Owl, tells him the same story but changes the Gruffalo's favourite food to owl ice cream. Owl quickly flies away. Similarly he tells Snake where he is going and that the Gruffalo's favourite food is scrambled snake. Snake quickly slithers away!Mouse eventually meets the Gruffalo, who tells him that he, the mouse, will taste good on a slice of bread. Mouse is undaunted and tells Gruffalo that he is the scariest creature in the wood and sets out to demonstrate that fact to him.Mouse proves his point with help from Fox, Owl and Snake and the Gruffalo is astounded. When Mouse tells him that his favourite food is Gruffalo Crumble, the Gruffalo turns and, quick as the wind, flees. Meanwhile the mighty Mouse finds a nut and enjoys his lunch!A lovely book for the children to read and play with and a lovely addition to any Julia Donaldson/Axel Scheffler collection.
Can't believe I'd never read this before! Super fun to read aloud, great cadence, non-stupid rhymes, and a very clever little mouse! We've already read it 5 or 6 times two days.

The Gruffalo is a brilliant story from Julia Donaldson with great illustrations throughout.This is a story about a clever mouse who is trying to make his way through the woods to find something to eat. However on his way he encounters other animals who want to have him for their dinner, so the mouse decides to tell them that he has a friend who is a Gruffalo so that the other animals will leave him alone.First of all the mouse meets a fox who tries to get the mouse to follow him to his "underground house" to have lunch. When the mouse explains to the fox that he cannot have lunch with him because he is going to have tea with a Gruffalo, he describes the terrible creature and to scare the fox away he tells him that the Gruffalo's favourite food is "roasted fox", however when the fox is out of view the mouse says to himself that there is no such thing as a Gruffalo. The mouse continues to walk through the woods when he comes across an owl. The owl also attempts to lure the mouse into his house to have him for his tea until the mouse describes other parts of the Gruffalo which is equally terrifying. The mouse manages to get rid of the owl by telling him that the Gruffalo's favourite food is "owl ice cream". The mouse finally meets a snake who has the same plans as the fox and the owl. The mouse describes the Gruffalo to the snake and as the snake slides away the mouse is about to say to himself again that there is no such thing as a Gruffalo when he suddenly notices that there is a Gruffalo standing right in front of him. The mouse panics because now the Gruffalo has plans to eat him so he tells the Gruffalo that all of the other animals are afraid of him. So they walk back through the wood and encounter the same animals again the fox, the owl and the snake. Because the mouse had terrified them with the descriptions of the Gruffalo they immediately run away, this way the Gruffalo thinks that everyone is afraid of the mouse. In the end the mouse turns around and tells the Gruffalo that he is going to eat him so the Gruffalo ran away as fast as he could. This book is an enjoyable book to read and I feel that it would be ideal for young children from nursery upwards. It has some repetitive features in the story which will be good for children to join in either in whole class reading at story time or guided reading. The story is also very descriptive which can add to the imagination.

While the blurb was pretty clear on what happens, I was still expecting more when that blurb part was over.Sadly, it just turned out to be really boring and bland. I was hoping the mouse would do something fun with our Gruffalo, or that the name-sake of this book would have a bit more of a spotlight than he had in this book. He is just there, does some stuff, and then disappears. Wow. :| You can better call it something different then. Something like Stupid Mouse Makes Stupid Decisions. I am quite sad, I heard a lot about the Gruffalo book, lots of people seem to love it, but I just couldn't like this one. Maybe there can be another book, this time about the Gruffalo and it will tells about a day in the Gruffalo life. I would definitely love that more than a book about a mouse trying to smart his way out of things and then just casually go on with life.The art was pretty good though, that really saved the book from the 1 star. All in all though, this was a big disappointment. :|Review first posted at https://twirlingbookprincess.com

Have I mentioned that I LOVE Julia Donaldson? This is one of my absolute favourites of hers, the compelling and exhilarating story of the Gruffalo. She has such an amazing flair in her writing that just excites you and compels you to read it over and over again. It is not only a beautifully sustained narrative that can be used as an effective book for end of the day story time. It is perfect for young children who are progressing with their phonological awareness, due to the repetitive rhyme and rhythm which helps to establish patterns in language as well as anticipation of what is to come (silly old [fox, owl, snake] doesn’t he know? There’s no such thing as a Gruffalo!). Giving children the opportunity to participate and become familiar in establishing patterns of sounds and words, even if the actual phonemes and graphemes have not yet been mastered.

This is that Julia Donaldson book that brought her appreciation and fame. This definitely is one of the best children books authored by her. I loved her power of imagination and narrative. The book is one of the fine examples of classic children literature and I am glad that I read it to my 18 months old.

A classic "David and Goliath"-esque story, Julia Donaldson subverts expectations of readers, with a strong theme of appearances (expertly illustrated by the great Axel Scheffler, with a unique and contemporary art style unlike anything seen before) juxtaposing personalities. Donaldson creates complex and sophisticated commentary upon the society we live in today, suggesting that the ones who seem harmless are often the scariest. The ending is meticulously crafted with fabulous plot twists, and leaves something up to interpretation. Donaldson is truly a master of our time, The Gruffalo is a strong 5/5 stars.

I thought this was a brilliantly creative storybook! I love how Julia Donaldson uses repetition and rhythm throughout the story, with each animal asking “Where are you going to, little brown mouse”, with the brown mouse telling everyone about the scary, big Gruffalo! “His eyes are orange, his tongue is black, He has purple prickles all over his back.” It’s a brilliant way to introduce children with rhythm and repetition, and all children can get involved. Having animals in the story is a good chance for the children to point out the different animals that are introduced throughout the mouse’s journey, and it allows the children to go wild with their imagination to think what these animals would be like. It also makes you think that an animal really small can be just as scary, as we find out at the end that the mouse told the Gruffalo that everyone was scared of the mouse, not him! The illustrations as well are brilliant and it really captures the narrative of the story. This story would be brilliant to read to early years and Key Stage 1. You can ask the children in your class if they know anything about the animals that are being presented to us throughout the story. Also, this story is a great starting point to allow children to start being creative in their creative writing and poetry, with the use of rhythm and repetition.

The Gruffalo is a very enjoyable and cleverly written book by Julia Donaldson. A child’s imagination and enthusiasm are heightened throughout this book as they are gripped by rhyme, repetition and vivid imagery. There is also an aspect of suspense throughout the story. The children learn the names of different animals which may be found in a forest and also the names of their different habitats.We follow a very clever and witty mouse walk through a forest. The mouse is greeted by different predators, including a fox, an owl and a snake, which are all eager to invite the mouse to their habitat. The mouse, however, knows that each of these animals are only interested in having him for dinner. The mouse, consequently, invents a creature called a Gruffalo. The Gruffalo is described vividly and resembles a monster-like animal. Each of the Mouse’s predators are scared off by his interpretation of the Gruffalo. To the surprise of the mouse he bumps into a real Gruffalo. The Gruffalo explains how he would also like to have the mouse for dinner. “‘My favourite food’ the Gruffalo said. ‘You’ll taste good on a slice of bread!’” The witty mouse however reacts quickly and thus, tricks the Gruffalo. He tells the Gruffalo that he is the most feared creature in the forest, even though he may be small. He walks back through the forest with the Gruffalo to prove his point. Each of the mouse’s previous predators, however, sees the Gruffalo walk alongside him and immediately flee away. The Gruffalo believes they are afraid of the mouse when in reality they are afraid of the Gruffalo. The mouse exclaims that his favourite food is ‘gruffalo crumble’, this scares the Gruffalo and he too, flees from the mouse. The mouse is left alone in the forest to enjoy his dinner, ‘The mouse found a nut, and the nut was good’. There is a very important lesson in this story, it doesn’t matter how big or small you are once you are clever you can fool anyone. The mouse was the smallest creature in the forest that day and he fooled all his predators. The rhyming throughout the story keeps the child enthralled and engaged until the very last page. The can read along with the teacher in a classroom setting as the rhyming and repetition throughout the story is very easy to remember and very catchy. They also learn to use their imagination and develop an image of the scary Gruffalo in their heads. A lesson plan could encourage children to use their imagination by drawing and describing their own scary monster, like the Gruffalo. I would choose this book for an EYFS classroom to be read aloud with each voice changing appropriately for each animal.

The Gruffalo is a fantasy story based on an intelligent mouse who is the desired prey of three intimidating animals. In order to avoid being eaten as the mouse makes his way through the dark wood, the mouse must utilize clever tactics to trick and distract his predators. His predators include firstly a fox, followed by an owl and then a snake. The mouse creates an 'imaginary' figure in his head to frighten the predators. He proclaims to them that he is on his way to a feast with a Gruffalo, whom he depicts as being a fierce and frightening beast. This description alone forces the fox, the owl and the snake to flee in fear of the beast. In conjunction with this, each time the mouse frightens one of the animals away he proclaims in rhyme "Doesn't he know? There's no such thing as a Gruffalo!".However, with a twist in events the monster of his imagination appears in real life in front of his very own eyes. Unlike his successful strategy before, the mouse can no longer create an imaginary figure to scare the Gruffalo as he in fact was the original figure to begin with. The mouse must be coy and think of a plan quickly before he is gobbled up "on a slice of bread" by the Gruffalo. The mouse soon comes up with a plan, he has decided that he will convince the Gruffalo that he (the mouse) is the most terrifying creature in the deep dark woods. As the mouse revisits creatures of the wood with the Gruffalo, the mouse manages to successfully convince the beast that he, the mouse, is in fact the scariest creature in the wood.I really enjoyed reading this book. I found the story line enthralling and felt like I was sitting on the edge of my seat waiting to see what would happen next. I felt that it was a highly original tale and displayed an excellent use of credible fantasy in that although everything in the story was made up, it felt as though it was all happening for real. I would recommend this book for reception and key stage 1 years 1 and 2. I think this book would be an excellent resource to utilize in the classroom. The use of rhyme and repetition would help to encourage the children to engage with the story and interact by repeating some of the phrases like "Doesn't he know? There's no such thing as a Gruffalo!". I think it would be a good tool to teach the children how rhyme works, I would ask the children what rhymes with various words in the story in order to consolidate their knowledge and understanding of rhyme further.

The Gruffalo is a children story typically for ages 3-7 initially published in 1999, its success has lead to west end productions and Broadway as well as winning multiple awards.the story is about a cunning little mouse's walk in the woods. During he's walk he encounters different animals who invite him back to their home only so they can eat mouse. The cunning mouse tells the animals he plans to dine with he's friend the Gruffalo, he describes the features of Graffalo and claims that hes favourite animal happens to be them. This scares the animals and they flee. When mouse carry's on with he's walk he is surprised to see a real Gruffalo with all the features he thought he was inventing. The Gruffalo wanted to eat the mouse but again the mouse was cunning and said that he is the scariest in the forest. The Gruffalo agrees to follow the mouse back into the forest to demonstrate how feared he is and encounters all the animals in the order he met them. Each animal was terrified at the sight of the Gruffalo and each time the Graffalo was more impressed by the mouse's toughness. The cunning mouse took this to advantage and threatens to eat the Gruffalo which than flees. Julia Donaldson has written a very creative story which instantly captures the young wild imaginations that children have. This book can be a great starter for creative descriptive writing, I have read this book to a year two class and done some follow up work on creating our own monsters and describing their features as well as acting out these monsters (developing the use of adjectives and similes). The lessons were a great success because of the natural wild imagination that children already have! The book also makes use of rhyming couplets, synonyms and repetitive verses making it easy for children to remember and retell the story as well as join in at times. What I love about this book is that it is split into two parts, the second part requires children to use their memory and understanding skills to reiterate the order of which the mouse met the animals on his way into the forest.The story is without a doubt amusing for readers and listeners and conveys a smart message that that even the most threatening of monsters are not always as scary as they seem at first. A definite must read!!

The Gruffalo is a story about a mouse and the giant Gruffalo. The story starts off when the mouse goes on a adventure into the 'deep dark woods'. Along the way, the mouse encounters many predators; the fox, owl and the snake, knowing very well that they are eager to make him their prey, the mouse invents tales of a creature called the Gruffalo. The smart thinking mouse one by one leers off his predators by giving vivid description of the creature; 'terrible tusks and terrible claws, with terrible teeth in his terrible jaws. He has knobbly knees and turned out toes and a poisonous wart at the end of his nose. His eyes are orange, his tongue is black, he has purple prickles all over his back'. The mouse successfully wards off any potential harm and proudly sets off for the rest of his journey. Much to his astonishment, his figment of imagination turns into reality when he's confronted by the real Gruffalo. However, being the smart thinking mouse that he is, the mouse ends up convincing the Gruffalo that all the animals are scared of him and his favourite meal is 'Gruffalo crumble'. Ultimately his fight for survival leads him scaring off the Gruffalo and becoming the King of the Jungle!Donaldson instantly draws us into the 'deep dark woods' and our minds are captivated throughout the whole journey. This is a brilliant book that can be read to reception and KS1 children and thoroughly enjoyed by all. The illustrations used are great and go well with the text, as they allow the children to use their imagination and create their own image of this mystical creature throughout, setting the story alive. The use of repetition and rhyme engages the children, getting them involved and creating a sense of excitement within the classroom. It's an excellent opportunity to be used in literacy for KS2 children to develop their creative writing and for KS1 children where they can explore their imaginations and describe what they think the Gruffalo looks like. It could also be used during art lessons, giving the children a chance to draw their interpretation of the Gruffalo. At first glance, one would assume that it would be a scary read for younger kids but the dominant use of humour in the story eliminates the scary elements. It's a book that has been enjoyed for many years and will carry on being enjoyed down the years.

The Gruffalo is a fantasy story about a mouse travelling through the woods who encounters a series of would-be predators, but he scares them off by telling them that he's on his way to meet a fierce Gruffalo. "His eyes are orange. His tongue is black. He has purple prickles all over his back." After escaping a fox, an owl, and a snake, the story has a twist and the mouse actually comes face to face with the creature from his imagination which he described to the other animals. The clever part in the story is When the mouse actually encounters the Gruffalo, he manages to convince him that he is the scariest animal in the forest now. This book would be suitable for Early Years children aged about four years old, however it can even be enjoyed by adults. The short rhymes and their repetitive structure makes the Gruffalo a fun book to read aloud reinforcing words and giving children the opportunity to become familiar with the style of writing. It is a humorous story where the mouse is in constant peril but uses his brain to outsmart the other animals. Due to the encounters with all the different animals and also due to the situations the mouse finds himself in, the book could be read using different tones and levels of volume making it even more exciting. The book can even inspire activities such as role-play to be carried out, as children find it exciting and amusing to copy animals, make silly sounds and act out different emotions. Moreover, the vibrant colours and fantastic illustrations used in the book can help develop a child's imagination. The images captivate a child's attention and can be used as a method to strike up a conversation about what they think might happen next. The child may just enjoy studying the pages and pictures themselves as they seem enchanted by the story. The unique style of writing, immense description and also illustrations allows the reader/child to bring the story to life. The Gruffalo is a brilliant, interesting and fun book with a unique style of writing which makes it extremely enjoyable to read. The flowing rhyme, immense description and imaginatively illustrated makes it well-deserving of its 1999 Smarties Gold Award.

‘The Gruffalo’ by Julia Donaldson is about a clever little mouse and his dangerous journey through a wood where he meets three predators, a fox, an owl and a snake. To escape being eaten he invents a gruesome friend, The Gruffalo, that would happily eat them all. To his surprise the mouse meets the imaginary Gruffalo and has to use further cunning to escape being dinner for all four animals. 	This Story is cleverly written with simple repetitive language and a very clever and cheeky protagonist. By informing the reader of the intent of the mouse and the trick he plays on the animals, the audience is immediately hooked and included in the story. This story allows the audience to relate to the cheeky mouse and enjoy the trick he plays on the animals and even his surprise when he finds that the Gruffalo exists.	This story is an excellent choice for key stage one children and has many applications in the classroom. The Gruffalo as a character can be drawn on in art class for children to develop retrieval skills. The story has given a brilliant and detailed description of the Gruffalo and this creates a great opportunity for children to bring these ideas together to create their own version of this fearsome creature. 	As a class dialogue there are many topics to focus on. As a group a class can discuss; Why the mouse had to trick the animals? How the animals felt when they heard of the hungry Gruffalo and its favorite food? Why the Mouse was shocked to find the Gruffalo? This could lead into smaller group discussions and even creative writing with their own retelling of the story to enhance retrieval skills. They could also create their own versions of the gruffalo constructing a creature that could help on a person journey such as shopping, going on a trip to the park or even to school. 	Overall this is a great short story that can be used to inspire a classroom on many different levels. Through its success the Gruffalo has now become a brand and has developed many different types of merchandise and media, all which can be useful in the classroom to further children’s understanding of the story.

in the Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson, there is a sneaky little mouse that lies to carry on with his life. but in this case, he makes up a creature to scare his PREDATORS. but little does he know something out there may be lurking. I think this book is really good mainly because it is very funny especially when he uses what he thinks is a fake monster to his advantage. I recommend this book for children because it is very humorous and I feel like children would find it entertaining.
Dangerously good.

'The Gruffalo' tells the story of a clever and cunning mouse who uses quick thinking to protect himself from the threatening animals he encounters on his strolls through the deep dark wood. As the mouse encounters each predator he scares them away with the promise that he is meeting a Gruffalo for lunch. The mouse describes the imaginary Gruffalo to each predator, informing each predator that the Gruffalo's favourite snack is the predator themself. At the end of the mouse's travels he meets a Gruffalo who wants to eat him. The mouse convinces the Gruffalo to take a walk with him to realise how feared the mouse is and to scare the Gruffalo away. As the Gruffalo traces the mouse's steps he meets all of the mouse's predators, each in turn flees at the sight of the Gruffalo. The Gruffalo becomes fearful of the mouse, believing he is a threat. The Gruffalo then leaves the clever mouse, allowing him to escape all the dangers of the deep dark wood. I first read this book to a pre-school class at nursery and they thrived with excitement. This book comes to life when read aloud and young children feel the tension of the creatures in the wood as the mouse describes the Gruffalo. Slowly the reader is able to conjure up a vision of the mythological beast which leaves both adults and children on tender hooks, nervous and fascinated about what will happen next. I really loved this book; it made me feel like a big child lost in a world of fantasy and imagination. This book can be enjoyed by children from pre-toddler to adult. Younger children will love the beautiful illustrations whereas the older children can appreciate the storyline and the suspense that builds with every page. This book is a great story time read for the classroom, Julia Donaldson employs rhyme throughout making this picture book a fun read. Not only does this book entertain but it can also be used to help children develop the basic concept of rhyme and poetry. The detailed descriptions allow children to use their creativity and let their imaginations run wild.

This is a rhyming story about a large monster, known to the reader as the Gruffalo. This creature is invented by a very clever little mouse who is walking through the forest. He invented the Gruffalo because on his journey, through the forest, he comes across many predators who want to eat him. By creating this creature and telling his predators he is meeting the Gruffalo for lunch, he frightens them away.But then the mouse himself sees a real Gruffalo. Using all of his quick thinking, has to try to trick the Gruffalo, as the Gruffalo too wants to eat the little mouse.The cunning mouse encourages the Gruffalo to walk through the forest with him, to have him believe that he himself, although small, is the scariest creature in the forest.As they set off back through the forest, they pass each of the predators. One by one, they take one look at the Gruffalo and run away. However the Gruffalo, to his amazement, believes it is because of the mouse that they scarper.The mouse indicates at the end of the story that his favourite meal is "Gruffalo crumble" which causes the Gruffalo to run away from him. So like the other predators he too was tricked by the clever little mouse.This is a great book for both children and adults. Through the mouse's description of the creature, it enables both children and adults to create an image of the Gruffalo in their minds, and anticipating what will happen next.This book can definitely be appreciated by all ages. Children can enjoy the beautiful illustrations, whereas older children and adults can be left in suspense by the clever descriptions given to them by the mouse.Using rhyme helps to make the story fun to read. Also used in a classroom environment, when read to the children the repetition with the line "Doesn't he know, there's no such thing as a Gruffalo", enables the children to join in with the story.Overall this is an excellent book, highlighting the use of rhyme and repetition and also encouraging the children to use their imagination.

The Gruffalo – Julia Donaldson (Illustrated by Axel Scheffer)Take a walk with a mouse through the forest and see what excitement awaits. On his travels he meets a fox, owl, snake and the beastly gruffalo who all think he “looks good” for filling their hungry stomachs. With some bold, “quick thinking” the mouse tries to face them all down with an outrageous web of lies coming to an unlikely conclusion.Written in droll rhyme, immediately The Gruffalo grabs you and makes you want to read more. It is a book best suited for younger children; I would suggest those in key stage 1, particularly as it can be accompanied by cuddly toys from the story. The cute artwork lends to the feeling of this being a book most appropriate for young children as older children may feel it is a little young for them.Using repetition at key moments there is plenty for children to feel familiar with as the tale unfolds. This provides the opportunity for review and discussion in a memorable manner at key moments and at the end of the book. I would recommend this book as one for whole class and then it could be used to introduce a number of activities as suggested below:•	The story could be used as a basis a drama activity looking at the use of characters. Groups could be given characters from other familiar stories and asked to create a short play showing how they may react in the same situation as the mouse.•	The artwork in this book would be used as a catalyst for discussion around differing forms of art through comparison and juxtaposition.•	Pairs or groups could formulate arguments for and against why the mouse is a nice or good character. •	The Gruffalo could be used as the catalyst for an investigation of poetry and the use of rhyme, particularly the advantages of poetry and rhyme being best when spoken and listened to.•	Using pictures and speech bubbles, this book could be used as an introduction to writing simple sentences or for higher level or older students, alternative sentences to the story.

The Gruffalo is about a mouse that firstly meets different animals in the woods that are prepared to eat him, such as: The fox, the owl and the snake. Each of these animals then ask the mouse to come inside and eat with them, although the mouse realises that this is an invitation for them to eat him he then decides to tell each animal that he has to decline the invitation as he plans to eat with his friend the gruffalo. The mouse then adds to the description of the gruffalo by stating that he is a grizzly bear and buffalo hybrid who likes the taste of either ‘fox, owl or snake’ depending on which of the animals he is talking to, with this description each of the animals then run away in fear. After telling each of the animals the fictional character he states: ‘Silly old fox/owl/snake, doesn’t he know? There’s no such thing as a gruffalo!’ Upon saying those words the gruffalo appeared in front of the mouse and threatened to eat him. The mouse then said that he was the scariest creature in the woods and decided to prove this to the gruffalo by walking with him past the differentanimals he had told the gruffalo about earlier who decided to flee once they had seen the gruffalo was real. The gruffalo was now convinced that the mouse was the scariest animal in the woods, taking advantage of this, the mouse then said he usually ate gruffalo and upon hearing this, the gruffalo ran away.I think that this book would be good in the early years setting, as it would encourage children to explore different emotions. The line ‘Silly old fox/owl/snake, doesn’t he know? There’s no such thing as a gruffalo!’ also introduces children to rhyme and poetry. The amount of description in the book would encourage children to be more descriptive and would help them to increase their vocabulary.

A new twist on the classic children’s rhyming tales. The central character, a small mouse, is taking a peaceful stroll through the woods to find himself some lunch. Along the way he meets a fox, an owl and a snake- all of whom are hungry and think the mouse would make a tasty treat. To each of them in turn the mouse describes a fictitious creature he is going to meet that he names a ‘Gruffalo’. Each description becomes further embellished with this creature’s garish and frightful characteristics until the mouse is alone in a clearing and, incidentally, runs into a real life Gruffalo! The mouse becomes frightened as the Gruffalo expresses an interest in eating him; however he manages to convince the simple Gruffalo that he is the most feared beast in the forest and sets out to prove this, revisiting the fox, owl and snake who immediately spy the feared Gruffalo and scarper. The naïve Gruffalo falls for this simple trick and bolts for the deep woods when the mouse turns to him and explains that his favourite food happens to be Gruffalo crumble. The mouse is then finally left alone to enjoy his lunch of a tasty nut.This is a feel-good tale told in rhyme where the under-dog comes out triumphant. The beautiful illustrations and grumpy yet loveable character of the Gruffalo coupled with the positive message to always stand up for yourself highlight so obviously why this book has been, for the last 3 years, one of the most popular young children’s books available.The recommended age range for this book would be around 4-5 years but possibly could be extended to 8 years if working with predominantly SEN students. It could be used in a classroom setting not only for private reading but also could be adapted into a script and used in a drama class discussing rhyming couplets.

This is a very enjoyable book to read,great for both children and parents. The book tells the story of a mouse's walk in the woods. On his way the mouse comes across 3 dangerous animals (a fox, an owl, and a snake). Each of these animals, clearly intent on eating the mouse, by inviting him back to their home. The crafty mouse declines each offer. He tells each animal that he has plans to eat with his friend, a gruffalo, whose favourite food happens to be the relevant animal, and describes the features of the gruffalo. What the animals do not know is that the mouse is actually inventing the gruffalo, and it not actually real; well so the mouse thinks.After getting rid of the last animal, the mouse is shocked to come across a real gruffalo – with all the frightening features the mouse thought that he was inventing. The gruffalo threatens to eat him, but again the mouse is crafty: he tells the gruffalo that he, the mouse, is the scariest animal in the forest. The gruffalo agrees to follow the mouse as he shows how feared he is. In fact all the animals that they encounter (the fox, the owl and the snake) as the two walk through the forest are terrified by the sight of the pair. The gruffalo was impressed with the mouse's apparent toughness. Exploiting this, the mouse threatens to eat the gruffalo, who then runs off.The book itself is vividly illustrated, with colourful pictures drawn in a child manner, to accompany the text. The rhyme in the book is also very fun, and the rhymical style of reading allows the children to get into character and recite verses. It is a book that makes the children want to know more about what happens next escpecially more about the monster that the mouse describes "A gruffalo!Why, didn't you know?".Overall a great fun book for everyone.

The Gruffalo in my opinion is one of the most enjoyable and creative books written for young children from ages three to five. The book comes alive with contrasting characters which attract the children's attention and draw them in. The main little amusing character that captures our attention is the clever mouse who manages to trick all his predators and escapes the possibilities of been a meal that evening. The little mouse does this by inventing a make believe scary animal called 'The Gruffalo'. However it turns out that this animal is not make believe when the mouse bumps into him in the woods. However the little mouse also tricks ;The Gruffalo'. This story is great as the children enjoy the rhythmic sounds throughout. The different use of animal characters gives the teacher/reader a chance to make the book come alive changing their tone of voice for each animal. Children thrive on this type of reading. For example for the charater of the snake, all the 's' letters can b dragged out to sound like a hissing snake. This adds flavour to the story telling session and encourages the children to pay attention. This book proved to be a great success from my experience with five year old children. They were intrigued and listened attentively to the quirky little rhymes 'terrible tusks, terrible claws, terrible teeth and terrible jaws'. It is a great book to base lessons on and even to get the children to draw their own 'Gruffalo' from all the descriptions listed throughout the book. The Gruffalo is beautifully illustrated which makes it even more appealing to the little readers. I rate this book as one of the most enjoyable, appealing and useful picture books for this age group.

This is a children's classic and we have been reading this to our daughter since she was around 10 months old. She loved the beautiful illustrations by the talented Axel Scheffler, that are so vidid and lifelike yet still imbued with a child's view of the world. The story of a little vulnerable mouse outwitting various hungry predators in the woods and nearly coming undone by his own tall tales is very simple to read to children and for them to learn language with but it is also extremely smart and sharp from an adult's perspective.Many children's books rely on the surreal or stretching what adults consider logical into completely fantastical tales that make little sense in any world and serve no purpose other than to try too hard to impress. The Gruffalo does not do this. It uses myth to make it's point but it is grounded in very down to earth ideas and narrative.The deliciously worded descriptions of The Gruffalo were fun for our daughter to read yet simple enough for her to remember and aid the development of her language skills. the illustrations play a big part in this as ideas such as knobbly Knees mean nothing to a toddler unless they can see them!When meal times became an endless chore of trying to convince our little one to eat her dinner we always had this book as a back up to distract her. It always worked and she always jumped straight into the wonderful world of the woods with the Mouse strolling through to meet the "imaginary" Gruffalo!A must for all parents.

Julia Donaldson & Axel Scheffler: The Gruffalo'A mouse took a stroll through the deep dark wood, a fox saw the mouse and the mouse looked good'This charming and captivating picture book recounts the uncertain journey of a courageous and streetwise little mouse through the deep dark wood. Throughout his excursion the mouse is met by different woodland animals all of whom wish to invite him for lunch. Cleverly devising that he himself may become the 'piece de resistance' little mouse declines saying he's having lunch with a gruffalo who has 'terrible tusks and terrible claws and terrible teeth in his terrible jaws'. Managing to deceive and outsmart the preying woodland creatures little mouse continues on his path until he comes face to face with the very real and very hungry gruffalo himself! What can he do in order to escape?!This clever and humorous tale is delivered through 'bounce off the tongue' rhyming text, which is appealing to young children who are grasping sound recognition and language comprehension, and also a collection of quirky and fun illustrations that not only fascinate young minds, but also serve as a tool in facilitating the language acquisition and language comprehension process. The pattern and repetition within the story engages children making the story much more fun and also encourages them to join in.This book is a great book for children between the ages of 3-6, touching on curriculum subjects such as English and Geography this book has masses of potential to be used in a variety of fun and educational ways.

The ‘Gruffalo’ is an extremely witty book, I was left in stitches when I read it, and I can honestly say I can read it over and over again. This story is about a very clever little mouse who outsmarts all the different animals in the forest to avoid being eaten. This story really highlights that, looks can be deceiving as this tiny little mouse manages to evade danger of being eaten through intelligence alone. This story shows that strength does not always manifest itself as a physical thing; rather one can have a lot of strength which can be demonstrated by their intelligence. I feel to some extent this book can empower children as they can learn that size really does not matter.This story is essentially about a mouse’s journey through the woods whereby the mouse makes up a fictional character “Gruffalo” in order to avoid being eaten. All the animals flee feeling scared that the Gruffalo will eat them. Ironically the mouse coincidently meets an actual Gruffalo. Once again the mouse uses his intelligence to outsmart the Gruffalo. I think the underlying message in this story is that intelligence can help in many situations; it’s also an empowering book, which highlights that size does not matter. The book has subtle under tones about being judgemental as it is very easy to judge people based on how they look, I suppose it highlights the importance of not being judgemental. I would recommend this book for Nursery children as well as KS1.Another must read for lots and lots of laughter!!! A timeless classic!

This story is about a mouse’s journey through a forest where along the way he finds himself face to face with 3 different predators, a fox, an owl and a snake. On each occasion he scares them off by describing a terrifying animal called the Gruffalo, whom he believes to be imaginary. That is until he actually crosses paths with one himself. Again the mouse cleverly outwits the Gruffalo by telling him that he himself is the scariest animal in the forest and to prove this he asks the Gruffalo to follow him. He then sees each of the animals he previously met and of course on seeing the Gruffalo, they all run away. The Gruffalo thinks that they are all scared of the mouse and so he himself makes a quick getaway.I believe this story is aimed at children aged 5-7 and demonstrates that quick-thinking along with a sense of courage, can help you to succeed in the most challenging of situations. The author has used rhyming couplets as well as repetition, which makes it an excellent read as part of a class reading session. The story can be used as a basis for a literacy lesson as the use of adjectives to describe the Gruffalo can help develop children’s vocabulary and imagination. The teacher can brainstorm different describing words based on what the children can see from the colourful illustrations. In addition, the children can recreate scenes of the story in groups as part of a drama lesson and also come up with ideas as to which animals the mouse can encounter next if the story was to continue. This would develop their ability to work together and encourage creativity.

A well known book by most children and now starting as a series on TV. The story is set in a forest and the main character is a mouse. The mouse frightens all his friends by telling them he is due to have lunch with a 'Gruffalo'. Little do they know, the little mouse is a invented character he uses to amuse himself by scaring others. All of a sudden he sees this character he has made up in front of him. The story takes twist as he tells the Gruffalo that everyone is afraid of the him the mouse, not Gruffalo and finally when he tells the Gruffalo that his favourite meal is 'Gruffalo-crumble', the Grufallo runs away leaving the mouse to enjoy his nut. I found this story enjoyable as it is humorous and builds up creating anticipation. In my opinion this book is aimed at children between the ages 3-6 and can be used to be read aloud to the class. This can be used as part of home-time reading activity to entertain or as part of a drama played by the class to encourage confidence and character. whilst reading out loud to engage the children the teacher can adopt different voices for each character as well as using hand gestures such as rubbing the belly saying 'gruffalo-crumble' and 'owl-icecream'. Another way this book maybe be used in a classroom is to introduce the story and lay the task for the children to write their own story with a character made up by themselves. This will build up their creativity and help them use linguistic devices such adjectives, metaphors and similies ect. A great book overall!

The Gruffalo follows the story of an extremely bright mouse who manages to escape an uncertain end by successfully deceiving not just one animal but three - a fox, owl and a snake. The mouse tricks all three animals by insisting he is meeting the Gruffalo - a mystical creature who is described in a frightening manner with the aim of scaring the animals away. However after these animals scupper, the tiny mouse is in fact greeted by the Gruffalo in a somewhat sinister manner. Nevertheless, the mouse manages to yet again escape the sticky situation and survive.I have chosen this book because at the core it has a classic theme - the tale of the underdog who succeeds against the odds, and shows that strength or success does not always come in a conventional manner. Although the suggested age range for this book is 5 - 11 year olds, in my view those in early years would alos find it enjoyable for class reading sessions. The Gruffalo is suitable for activities in many subjects across the curriculum. The text can be used to lead literacy lessons as the book features many rhyming words and also a wide variety of different punctuation. In addition the story is useful for science lessons when studying the food chain as the place of the different animals featured in the story can be looked at. Finally the book can be used for art lessons where pupils can create their own Gruffalo style creature.

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson is a fantastic award-winning children’s book. After reading this book to a year 1 class, I recommend it to all early years teachers and parents. The school library or the bookshelf at home isn’t quite complete without this book. It has recently become one of my personal favorites. The book tells the story of a brave mouse who decides to take a stroll through the deep dark woods. On the course of his walk, he comes across different animals such as a Fox, an Owl and a snake that all desire to eat him. To each animal he comes across, the mouse explains that he is on his way to meet his friend the Gruffalo, and describes his scary appearance. This I turn frightens the animals away and the clever mouse avoids being eaten. Children barely get bored of hearing this story read. The repeated line “there’s no such thing as a Gruffalo” really gets children engaged and involved in the story. The humor found in this book is age appropriate and entertaining. The rhyming gives the story a great flow and makes it simple for children to follow. On the other hand, this book may indirectly be teaching children that dishonesty is permissible. Beautiful illustrations by Axel Scheffler fill the pages of the book. This is a good read for EYFS and KS1 children. The book can also be used in English lessons, role-play and possibly circle time activities.
