A great children’s book of all time, The Gruffalo is a story about a very intelligent mouse and how he adventures through a dangerous forest escaping the ferocious animals that lurk around by claiming to meet The Gruffalo, known to be the most scariest and ferocious monster alive. By doing so he passes through all the animals without a scratch, and by meeting the Gruffalo himself, he manages to stay alive and well.I really enjoyed reading this book because the first thing I thought about was the tactic of survival and clearly the mouse knew it all too well. Children will automatically feel that because the mouse is small it won’t survive but in actuality it can and does. I think the best age for this book would be children in year 1 so children aged 5-6 years old. The creativity behind the story and the illustrations to match up each other, help the children feel curious and ponder upon what might happen to the mouse.This book can be read to the children as a whole class, and may set up activities in relation to the story such as being able to write the story from beginning, middle and end by using strips of sentences with the pictures that may come with it. This book should definitely be available for independent reading and allow children to explore the story on their own or as a group.

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson, is an entertaining story of a cunning, imaginative mouse. While taking a walk through the woods our protagonist, the clever mouse, devises a plan in an attempt to protect himself from the various predators (fox, owl, snake ) that want to eat him . He tells each of these animals that he is going to meet a Gruffalo and each time he gives a detailed description of this creature the he has seemingly made up in his mind. He succeeds in frightening away the animals, but then he meets the animal of his imagination- a Gruffalo!Now he must deal with the Gruffalo who also wants to eat him! The mouse tells the Gruffalo to walk behind him through the woods and see how all the other animals fear him. The Gruffalo is sceptical that other animals would be frightened of a mouse. He walks behind the mouse, and when the animals of the woods see the Gruffalo behind the mouse they runaway with fright and the Gruffalo believes that the mouse was telling the truth and ends up running away with fear himself. This is a very accessible story to explore with children in EYFS and KS1 and it teaches them about various animals and their natural habitats. I also like the rhyme throughout the book and I think it makes it easier to follow for young children. I hope to read this book to my year 1 class during SBT2 as I think they will enjoy it as much as I have.

This was a fantastic book cover, this generated a wide range of discussion with the children i taught last week. great illustrations are important in any children's book, but this book's ilustration was very vivid and clear. which also helped and is fantastic during guided reading.The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson and illustrated by Axel Scheffler quickly became a rhyming success at quiet time and nap time with the children with lots of illustrations, a snappy rhythm; written in Iambic Pentameter making it fun to read aloud. The children loves reading with repetition and we found that she jumped in and start telling us the story herself after one read.The book tells the story of a little mouse who takes a stroll through the deep dark wood where he encounters a number of scary creatures who would like to take him home and make him their dinner, all pretty scary if you are a mouse but none so scary as the Gruffalo. Reading along to see what a Gruffalo is and how our mouse evades becoming a snack is a fun and entertaining book with a great twist that allows for the underdog of the story to put one over on the big guys! It's not easy to find a book that doesn't get boring to read after the first 20 re-reads and The Gruffalo fits happily in the read it over and over category with ease.

The Gruffalo is a story about a cunning mouse who meets a fox, an owl and a snake in the woods. One by one, the mouse tricks the animals into believing that he is friends with a beastly animal called the Gruffalo. The mouse describes the Gruffalo as having "a wart above his nose" and "inward turned toes." The animals get really scared when hearing this and run as far away as they could. To the mouse's dismay, he actually encounters a real life gruffalo in the woods, who tells the mouse that his favourite dish is a "nice mouse in bread." At once the mouse becomes frightened and derives a cunning plan to scare away the gruffalo. The mouse makes the Gruffalo walk behind him in order to scare away the other animals, but the Gruffalo thinks the mouse is scary. The Gruffalo then runs away and in the end the mouse is safe!As a child, this was one of my absolute favourite books. I loved the fact that the whole book was written as a rhyme, making it such a good read. Also, the illustrations were really helpful in telling the story. This book is for younger readers, Key Stage 1 students, because it is a fun book to read. It can be read as a whole class, allowing the children to sing along to it, as there are many repeating events in the story. Children can be asked to create a picture of their own scary monster, by getting help from the adjectives in the book.

The Gruffalo encourages children to use their imaginations throughout the whole book, keeping them engaged and anticipating the next page. The reader is first introduced to a mouse who is wandering through the woods. On his travels, the mouse encounters numerous other animals who, alas!, want the mouse for their tea! However, the mouse outsmarts them all by inventing a terrifying monster, named the Gruffalo, who would like to have them for his tea!The mouse is rather amused that he has managed to trick the animals in the woods into believing that the Gruffalo is real, so imagine his surprise when he himself comes face to face with the terrifying Gruffalo! But the dastardly mouse once again outsmarts yet another character in the book when he manages to convince the Gruffalo that all the animals in the wood are scared of him. The Gruffalo panics when he believes that all the animals are fleeing from the mouse and even more so when the mouse reveals that his favourite food is Gruffalo crumble. The Gruffalo is a hugely popular children's book, suitable for both key stage 1 and 2. The format of the book is a fantastic rhyming scheme which really encourages children to join in, read along and become thoroughly immersed in the story. The book is beautifully illustrated and the characters in the book come alive on every page. A must have in every primary school classroom.

•	This is the story of a clever little mouse walking through the forest trying not to get eaten. Along the way several predators invite mouse over for dinner, each time he tells the predator of his friend, the Gruffalo. who is truly terrifying. Little did the predators know there’s no such thing as a Gruffalo. Or maybe there is. •	Pre-k -3•	I would use this book in my classroom during English.•	In my classroom I would read this book aloud then ask each individual student to create their own Gruffalo. What characteristics would the Gruffalo have? •	Small groups could use this in literature circles, along with books like I need my monster by Amanda Noll to create their own monsters. Students should be as descriptive as possible. •	I would use this book with the whole class as a read aloud to talk about being descriptive. How do we know what the Gruffalo looks like without looking at the pictures? o	Students can be illustrators. Read the book to students without showing them the pictures, cover the book’s cover, have students draw the Gruffalo without ever seeing the pictures. Compare Gruffalos, then show students the pictures in the book. •	Other books that students may enjoy include I Need My Monster by Amanda Noll •	The Gruffalo is distributed to children by Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library. It is available as an e-book on amazon.
Great book for young children, funny for older audiences too! Has some repetition but not too much and helps kids remember some of the story better. The rhymes in this book are funny as well!

Children love this story, esp if you change your voice for different charactors. This was used in the nursery to use repetative words, the children end up saying the last few words with you, this also encourage's the children to keep even more engaged. Brilliant story would read upto age of around 7 or 8. children always like a good fun story until then !!! 

The Gruffalo by Julia DonaldsonChildren love this story, esp if you change your voice for different charactors. This was used in the nursery to use repetative words, the children end up saying the last few words with you, this also encourage's the children to keep even more engaged. Brilliant story would read upto age of around 7 or 8. children always like a good fun story until then !!! View all my reviews

Mouse goes for a stroll through the deep, dark wood along the way encountering menacing characters that want to eat him. However, mouse has a cunning plan! He formulates a fearsome creature (the Gruffalo) to scare off the characters, not realising that his fantastical notion really does exist! Face to face with the real Gruffalo, the quick thinking mouse asserts that HE in fact is the scariest creature in the wood. Intrigued, the Gruffalo takes a walk with this 'big, bad mouse' back through the wood meeting all the previous characters along the way. In a tale of clever manipulation and quick thinking, the legend of the 'big, bad mouse' is born.Julia Donaldson uses repetition and rhyme resulting in a book that is fun to read and join in with. The book is beautifully illustrated by Axel Scheffler adding to the captivating nature of the book. Together they bring elements of tame fear and fun in a book that both children and adults alike do not want to end!I love reading this book to my children as it allows different voices to be used which draw in the listener and adds suspense.The Gruffalo is appropriate for children aged between 3-7. It could be used in the class room to demonstrate and develop creative and descriptive writing.

“The Gruffalo” by Julia Donaldson is a bright, colourful cheerful book that captures the presence of wild animals both big and small in the middle of a woodland area.The story involves a fox, an owl, a snake and its two main characters a mouse and “the gruffalo”. In turn, the mouse bumps into each of these characters and one by one he is ironically scares each of them away, who all have come for a taste of him. He quickly comes up with what he believes is an imaginary, make believe animal, “a gruffalo”, which makes each of them run away from him, fearing for their lives. To his surprise the gruffalo comes to life and he has to do his best to scare him off also which he manages to do very successfully.This book is perfect for a story-time session, allowing children to become engrossed in what could be a very happy or sad ending for the tiny mouse. It would also give children a good opportunity to use their imaginations and create a descriptive impression of what each of these animals might actually look like. A word bank could also be created by the children after reading this book as there is a huge amount of descriptive language used throughout the book. I found this book thoroughly enjoying and would look forward to using it in a classroom setting.

The GruffaloA witty story about a mouse who takes a stroll through the woods, trying not to be eaten by the other woodland creatures. The mouse wants to avoid becoming the fox’s lunch, the owl’s tea or the snake’s dinner. The mouse fabricates a tale of the Gruffalo which scares each of the creatures it meets along the way. Pleased with himself, the mouse continues his stroll until he comes face to face with the Gruffalo, who the mouse thinks is not real. The Gruffalo wants to eat the mouse however the mouse tells the Gruffalo all the animals are scared of his presence. He then retraces his steps with the Gruffalo by his side to meet the owl, fox and snake who the mouse introduces. All three animals stumble away from the Gruffalo but the Gruffalo think they are all scared of the mouse, causing him to fear the little cunning brown mouse as well. In the end the mouse gains a reputation of being fearsome and is able to continue taking a stroll through the woods without being disturbed.This story is a delightful read, using rhymes to ensure this story is memorable. This would appeal to children aged between 4-7 years; it could be read independently or with the teacher reading aloud to the class.

The Gruffalo (Julia Donaldson)The Gruffalo tells the story of a mouse on his travels through a forest. On his journey, the mouse meets many dangerous animals who want to eat the mouse. He tells the animals that he is on his way to meet his friend, the Gruffalo; half grizzly bear, half buffalo. Once the animals hear this, they leave in fear. Each time the mouse says, 0‘Silly old snake (or other animal), doesn’t he know?There’s no such thing as a Gruffalo!’As he walks through the forest, the mouse meets a Gruffalo. Terrified, the mouse tries to convince the Gruffalo that he is the most feared animal in the forest. As the Gruffalo follows him through the forest, the other animals see the Gruffalo with the mouse and run away in fear.This is a fantastic book and I remember it being read to me as a child. I particularly liked this books because of the tricks the mouse plays on the other animals in the forest. I enjoyed this book as it allows its readers to run away with their imaginations. I enjoyed this book because of its humour and the cunning way in which the mouse can trick the animals.This book would be particularly enjoyable to pupils in key stage one and I would like to study this book with my pupils in the future.

I came across this book for the first time when my friend’s 4 year old son told me that he wanted to read his favourite story to me. I enjoyed it so much that I went out and bought my own copy!This book tells the story of a little mouse’s encounters as he takes a walk through the deep, dark wood. Unfortunately for the mouse, the other woodland creatures see him as tasty morsel and pretend to invite him to their homes for a meal. The brave mouse, however, does not seem the least bit alarmed at the possibility of ending up on a dinner plate. Instead, he uses his quick wit to make up an imaginary creature called a gruffalo, which is so frightful that it scares away his potential predators. But will the mouse be just as brave when he comes face-to-face with the fearsome creature that he thought was completely made up?The simplicity, creativity and rhyme of this book make it an excellent choice to read with children in nursery or reception. Children will find it difficult to resist the temptation of joining in; adults will find it difficult to resist the temptation of acting out the characters.

This is one of my all time favourites!!A clever mouse is walking around the deep dark wood and encounters many animals on his way, including a fox, an owl and a snake. Knowing that the animals would eat him, the mouse invents a mythical creature he is going to see called the gruffalo. The gruffalo is indeed a creature to be scared of!!Now eventually he actually meets a real life gruffalo and knowing that the gruffalo intends to eat him as well he shows the gruffalo how scary the animals in the forest find him. He has the gruffalo follow him back through the wood and the fox and the owl and the snake are all scared when they see the pair coming; the gruffalo thinks that the mouse is indeed a fearful creature and runs away.This is a fantastically writen book, using rhyme and poetry. The illustrations are colourful and descriptive and really match what is happening in the story. This is an excellent book to use in role-play and really good when working with adjectives. Would make a fabulous class display with lots of discribing words being used. I would recommend for KS1.

I found this an excellent read and a book that I believe would be valuable for any child especially those between the ages of 4 - 8. Enchanting story about a cute little mouse who manages to trick the animals in the forest who want to eat him by telling them of an "imaginary" monster - the Gruffalo. They're truly terrified and leave him alone. Imagine the mouse's surprise when he comes face to face with the terrifying Gruffalo himself who also wants to eat the little mouse. Again, the cute little mouse has a cunning plan and tells the Gruffalo that all the animals are terrified of him (the mouse) and he proves his point by walking back through the forest with the Gruffalo at his side. Of course the animals run for their lives when they see the Gruffalo and the Gruffalo thinks the mouse is someone to be afraid of, not realising that it is he they are running from. This is an excellent book for children with rhyming text and wonderful illustrations. I can't imagine anyone could resist this book. If your ever stuck for literacy ideas its packed with them. A great read, full of excitement.

Brain over brawnAn acquaintance with young children lent me this book, when he knew I was interested in writing children's stories myself. He said his children loved the book and, once I'd read it, I could see why. It's a beautifully illustrated tale, demonstrating how brain can overcome brawn, as a small mouse escapes the clutches of various, dangerous woodland animals by threatening them with a huge, hideous and apparently imaginary creature called the Gruffalo, only to then be met by the huge, hideous creature himself (perhaps another moral here i.e. be careful what you wish for, you may get it). So he is then required to exercise his ingenuity once more to escape becoming a tasty Gruffalo dinner. The rhyming verse appealed to the poet in me and, in my opinion, makes the story an ideal one to be read out loud to young children and aquaint them with new vocabulary. I wish I had come across this book sooner, when my niece and nephew were younger, because they would have loved it!

I read this book on SEA to a nursery class and they absolutely loved it. The story is about a mouse's journey through the woods who meets a number of other animals such as a fox, an owl and a snake. Each of these animals wish to eat him but in order to prevent this from happening, the mouse makes up what he believes is an imaginary animal called the 'Gruffalo' and states that he is going to have lunch with this Gruffalo. The Gruffalo is described as a terrifying animal who enjoys eating: roasted fox, owl ice-cream and scrambled snake. This soon results in the animals leaving the mouse on his own to continue his journey. But little does the mouse expect to actually bump into the Gruffalo! And the Gruffalo wants to eat him. So the mouse uses his wit to scare the Gruffalo off of eating him - and it works!An absolutely enjoyable read with the use of rhyme which I believe children in nursery, reception and even year 1 can enjoy. It could also possibly be used when introducing writing using rhyme.

The Gruffalo is a particular favourite book of mine as it is beautifully designed and easy to read. The story outlines a mouse’s journey through a “deep dark wood” who meets different woodland creatures along the way. This story has a clever twist as all the woodland creature who meet the mouse try and invite him in for tea, however every time the mouse replies “I’m going to have lunch with a Gruffalo”. The mouse terrifies each of the animals by describing the Gruffalo and at the end of the story then terrifies the Gruffalo himself.This book highlights rhyming words within a story as well as emphasising the importance of being able to say no to strangers and move away from them. It is also a great way to introduce woodland animals to young children and EAL learners. This book could be used with young children from 5 years old up to 8 years old (Years 1 to 3) in a literacy lesson to explore rhyming words in different settings. It is also captivating and so it would also be ideal of a whole class read.

The Gruffalo is an early learners book written by Julia Donaldson. The book is about a mouse that walks through the forest. On its walk, the mouse bumps into different types of animals that eat mice. The mouse scares them away by telling them he will meet a gruffalo. Towards the end of its journey, the mouse is shocked when it actually meets a gruffalo. The gruffalo wants to eat the mouse, but the mouse convinces the gruffalo that it is the scariest animal in the woods. As a result, the gruffalo respects the mouse and decides not to eat it. The Gruffalo could be read to a KS1 class. The book is a good introduction to adjectives for the pupils as they are used to describe the gruffalo. The pupils could write a poem about the gruffalo using adjectives and comparatives. The class could do this together on the carpet. After that, the pupils could create their own creatures and draw pictures of them. Next, the pupils could write poems about their creatures using adjectives and comparatives. They could decorate their work and put it on display.

The Gruffalo is a favourite book of mine that I read to my children all the time. The little brown mouse walks through the forest and uses an imaginary monster (the gruffalo) to discourage many animals in the forest from eating him. Towards the end the mouse finds that the Gruffalo is actually real and has to use his wit again to trick the Gruffalo into thinking he is the scariest creature in the woods, so funny. I love the way the story rhymes and flows so well, when reading it to my daughters, we do all the voices and make it exciting. I like the way the mouse uses his wit to trick the animals. Like a good film the 2nd and 3rd view offers something new, It’s a fun story which never fails to raise a smile. The author uses great vocabulary to describe the characters and the illustrations are good as well. Having worked in nurseries for a few years I have read this story to so many children, I have seen that the repetition and rhyming make it more approachable to join in and I haven’t had a child that didn’t enjoy the Gruffalo.

This book, by Julia Donaldson, is a wonderful book with a very intriguing storyline. The book tells the story of a little mouse as he takes a journey through a forest, alone. Along the way he is met with danger in the form of a snake, an owl and a fox. To avoid being eaten by these animals, the mouse invents the idea of a fierce animal that he calls a 'gruffalo'. Upon telling these predators that he is a friend of this 'gruffalo', the mouse is able to travel safely through the woods, only to be met by a 'gruffalo'! This book is suitable for children in both Early Years and Key Stage 1. It contains excellent illustrations and the rhyming pattern of this story keeps children interested throughout the entire book. This book could be read independently by Year 2 children but benefits from being read aloud to the whole class by the teacher. It can also be used to teach children about rhyme and lends itself to the introduction of creative writing. A very enjoyable story, it is one that the children will love to hear over and over again.

Donaldson has done a great job in creating a piece of text which has stood the test of time. I remember being in a classroom and listening to my class teacher read this story and being hooked to every word. It is a story about a wily mouse that strolls through the woods and speaks of a Gruffolo. The mouse’s intent to scare the animals that listen to the tale, the owl, fox and snake are all shaken by the description of this unknown creature. Eventually the mouse runs into the Gruffolo and he seems to be hungry for mice! The use of repetition within this text engages the readers and has proven to be a powerful tool within the classroom. Children have been fascinated by the story and the interaction that can be created by having the children repeat the phrase can really create and element of excitement within the classroom. It allows the readers to be vary of the mouse and creates a wonderment on whether the Gruffolo is real or not. Great to be used during story time, in guided reading or even independent reading.

The Gruffalo is a children’s book about a mouse who evades being eaten by claiming to be friends with an apparently made up creature who eats all of his enemies. It is in this way that the mouse perverts the food chain and uses the invention of the monster to protect him from predators. All goes well until he meets a Gruffalo who would rather eat him instead. This work is a fantastic example of one type of sentence fluency as the text has an almost musical quality. Each of the lines also rhymes and has a particular rhythm. I would share the book with my students in the form of a read aloud by Ollie Heath (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThZqD...) whose recording has background music, adding to the flow of the poetic writing. Students would then use this as a mentor text to create their own short children’s story or song. While their creation need not rhyme, it should have a rhythm and flow. After completing the assignment we would have a class read aloud. This work could also be an introductory piece to a unit on poetry.

The Gruffalo by Julia DonaldsonThis is a story about a clever little mouse who tricks the other animals in the wood, in order to protect himself and avoid being eaten. The mouse creates an imaginary character, the “Gruffalo”, to scare the other animals away and get through the wood safely. He describes the Gruffalo to the other animals as having “terrible tusks, and terrible claws, and terrible teeth in his terrible jaws". The language used in the story is simple, repetitive and the rhymes grip the attention of the reader, engrossing them in the story. The illustrations are colourful, descriptive and imaginative which complement the story excellently. It’s a very enjoyable book in which children can engage with a variety of activities such as acting out the story, discussion, playing the roles of the various animals and sequencing the story with pictures. This story is ideal for children in Early Years or Key Stage 1.

This is an entertaining story of an imaginative mouse who while taking a walk through the woods makes up a story about a animal he calls a Gruffalo , in an attempt to protect himself from the various predators (fox, owl, snake ) that want to eat him .He succeeds in frightening away the animals ,but than he meets the animal of his imagination- a Gruffalo. Now he has a bigger problem the Gruffalo wants to eat him, so he tells the Gruffalo to walk behind him through the wooods and see how afraid the animals are of him (the mouse that is ). The Gruffalo of course doesn't believe that the animals could possibly be afraid of a mouse so he walks behind the mouse , and when the animals of the woods see the Gruffalo behind the mouse they runaway in fright and the Gruffalo believes that the mouse was telling the truth and runs away from the mouse himself. Very enjoyable story to explore with children in EYFS and KS1.

The Gruffalo is a wonderful read and I enjoyed the book as much as the children. I read this story to a year 1 class as it was part of their English lesson and from the beginning till the end children were focused as they wanted to know what happens next. The story is about a clever little mouse who tricks the other animals such as the fox, owl and snake by inventing an imaginary animal called the Gruffalo who the other animals feared. This story is a trickster story and children found it funny how a little mouse was able to trick all the other animals. This story also has ryhme and chidlren found it easy to read and remember the words.Overall I think it is a lovely story that children can read during a guided reading lesson as there are many things that can be discussed. Finally there is a animated version of the story that children can enjoy watching too.

The story follows a mouse on a trek through the woods where he meets various intimidating animals who he manages to scare away by telling them about the scary Gruffalo. The book has great illustrations with engaging rhyming and repetition throughout. Predominately it can be used for 3-7 age range although can be enjoyed by all, although I used the it in my SEN class with pupils aged 10-11. As there is a lot of repetition and rhyming pupils can really interact with the story by pressing switches to complete the sentence. It also introduces children to a lot of adjectives. Pupils can complete matchng and sequencing activities to encourage their understanding of the story. There is also a lot of opportunity to make it into a sensory story (feel mud, stones, rocks, he different animal fur).

I loved this children's book. I borrowed it from placement to read. This book was about a mouse inviting different animals to tea but saying that a Gruffalo would eat them up. But then the mouse jokes that he isn't real. The mouse then bumps into the Gruffalo who says he wants to eat him up. The mouse says everyone in the woods is afraid of him and asks the Gruffalo to follow him. He follows and sees that they are scared but really they are scared of the Gruffalo because the mouse told them he would eat them up.I think this book showed a lot of alliteration such as 'scrambled snakes' and it helps children learn body parts such as when the Gruffalo's are listed. It also shows adjectives to describe the body parts which is good. I like the fact that the book rhymes as well because it adds rhythm. There is also a song on YouTube which the children love to join in with about the Gruffalo.

The Gruffalo is a wonderfully funny book in which woodland creatures Fox, Owl and Snake try to lure Mouse into their grasp, Mouse manages to outsmart them with his extremely wild and creative imagination by concocting a description of the fierce Gruffalo. However mouse is completely unaware of the Gruffalo’s existence ‘Silly old snake doesn’t he know there is no such thing as a Gruffalo’. On encountering the Gruffalo, Mouse uses his cunning wit to appear as the scariest creature in the deep dark wood. This book is beautifully illustrated with rhyming verses and repetition enabling children to join in with ease. It has educational elements and is suitable for all ages...including adults as I love this one!

I’ve heard a lot about this book but I have not read it until now. The books has morals to the story, one is not to lie! Also no matter how some one looks, you should never judge them. It is a great book for 3 -5 year olds.I like how the author describes all the features of the Gruffalo and how scary it can make you feel especially if you are a young child. The story captures the imagination of pre-schoolers as it takes them on a journey with mouse as he strolls through the wood and meets the beast himself, the Gruffalo. I really like the illustrations. It can really help children who don’t know how to read, it can help them imagine the story. It was nice how the sentences rhymed e.g. “dark wood” and “looked good”.I will recommend everyone to read this.

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson is an wonderful story of a mouse who encounters many problems on his journey through the forest. He is faced with various animals who try very hard to eat the little mouse. The mouse duissuades the creatures by telling them he is on his way to see his friend a Gruffalo, whos favourite food is the relevant animal. The mouse however, happens to bump into a real Gruffalo who he tricks into believing that the mouse himself is the scariest creature in the forest. As they go for a walk to prove this, every animal the mouse met on his way runs away with fear upon seeing the mouse. The rhyme in the story makes it enjoyable and the characters are humourous and likeable which makes this story engaging and a delight to read.

I see the point, but I can't help but object to the fox, snake, and owl being demonized in a modern story. (In the old folktale with the tiger, mentioned in the Children's Books group discussion, it's ok because the fact that it's a folk story gives it the step of remove.) Everyone needs to eat, and the fact is that mice are prey. And in fact I bet that if fans of this story found one in the house they'd react pretty negatively....And even if I shush myself from those objections, both my inner child and I object to the sudden appearance of an imaginary animal, looking just like, and being named just as, the mouse dreamed it up. Does the mouse have paranormal powers? Or can nightmares be brought to life? Just... disturbing. Sorry. Not a fan of Donaldson.

A story exploding with colour and wit!'The Gruffalo' – An inspiring book which takes story time on a journey through a vibrant forest landscape, accompanied by one brave little mouse and many scary encounters! I feel this book is poetically humorous and the vibrant illustrations by Alex Sheffler perfectly coincide with the stories magic charm.'The Gruffalo' teaches about courage, about how something so tiny like this little mouse can overcome his wildest fears through use of self belief and wiliness. I especially love the poetic flow of the story and use of repetitive questioning from the animals along with the frankly brilliant illustrations with attention to vibrancy.

‘The Gruffalo’ is a children's book by Julia Donaldson that tells the story of an innocent mouse's walk in the woods and the dangerous animals he encounters. Each of these animals has the intention of eating the mouse which he evades by telling each of them he has to dine with his friend, the Gruffalo, a fictional animal that the mouse invents, whose favoured food is each of the animals. The story revolves around the brave little mouse’s journey through the woods and the comical methods he uses to avoid his fate. This book is recommended for children between 2 and 6 but is a very enjoyable read for all ages.

A fun and friendly book aimed at EYFS and key stage one children. The Gruffalo contains poetry, repitition and rhyme which entertains young learners.I read this book to a year 2 class during my school placement and they really enjoyed the book and even read parts of it along with me. I also think that it would also be a good idea for children to act out different scenes of the story as there are various characters such as the mouse, fox, owl and the Gruffalo which children would be very excited to be a part of.I would definately recommend reading this book to KS1 children as it keeps them engaged and creates a calm, positive and inclusive environment in the classroom.

The Gruffalo carries its readers on an adventure that kids would only love to hear. I have to admit that I enjoyed reading this book myself. I found it humorous that the Gruffalo believed the mouse when he said that he was the scariest person that he would meet on the trip. This book could be used in early years whereby the children could follow the story and state what happens next because sequences is a huge part of the framework for Reception. The vivid imagery is brilliant in this story. I could imagine a role play area set up around this book. As well as that one could discuss different types of habitats. I really enjoyed reading this book and I feel the children would too.

The Gruffalo is a wonderful picture book. It tells the story of a cunning little mouse who meets various dangerous animals along his journey but cleverly avoids being eaten by inventing the mysterious creature called the Gruffalo. His journey goes well until he actually meets the Gruffalo...but the clever mouse has another trick up his sleeve...This picture book would be of interest to 3-7 year olds as it has a wonderful rhyming tone to it and the story would keep them engaged. The pictures are lovely and colourful for younger children to enjoy while the repetative tone of the story would encourage older children to join in and interact with the story.

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson is a very creative story which lets the imagination wonder. The story is about a clever little mouse, three animals and an imaginary monster, The Gruffalo. The three animals set out to eat the little mouse however he is far to clever to be defeated. The mouse scares these animals by inventing a monster that is actually after them. I really enjoy reading this book to my four year old nephew who never gets bored of hearing the story! The rhyming words, descriptive language, repetition and ideology of the mouse being the scariest animal makes it great fun. The story can be used in key stage one to explore rhyming words/repetition.

This is by far one of the best children’s books out there. It is about a mouse that goes on a journey through the woods and is confronted by 3 animals that all want to eat him and he comes up with a story that he is meeting an imaginary Gruffalo to scare them off. Just like the the Dr Seuss books, once you have read this a few times you will know it off by heart. You can really engage the children if you act out the story using the suitable voices. The illustrations are bright and capture the imagination. I love this book not only for the fantastic language and imaginative story but the child in me loves it too

I saw this book when shopping at World Market the other day. I remembered my British book club friend saying that she had read this story to her daughters many, many times and I hadn't heard of it before. Apparently the author is from England. Anyway, I stood and read this in the store and was charmed. It is a story told in verse of a small mouse who scares away predators who want to eat him by describing a monster called a Gruffalo. Adorable! I racked my brain thinking...who can I buy this for? I think I know someone now and will definitely be making a trip back to the store. My children always loved books that rhyme.

This is a picture book about a clever mouse who escapes being eating up by a fox, a snake and an owl by convincing them that a scary monster, 'The Gruffalo' exists and is his friend. However it backfired on him as it turns out the gruffalo actually did exist. In the end, the mouse was clever enough to avoid being eaten by the gruffalo and also trick it into being scared of him.  This book contains repetetive texts ryhming words and brightly coloured illustrations which would appeal to children in the early years foundation stage(EYFS).

This such a clever story about a witty little mouse who needs to go through the wood but is faced with the prospect of being eaten by the fox, owl and the snake so he invents this fearsome creature to frighten them off!! The language is simple, repetative and rhymes which grips the attention of all those who read and listen to it. The illustrations are equally brillient; colourful, detailed and very imaginative for all those young readers of EYFS and Key Stage 1...one they will return to time and again!!

I have read The Gruffalo to my 5 year old daughter, as she had enjoyed the animated version on TV. She thought that it was a great book and fun too. At first she was a little bit afraid of The Gruffalo but the more we read the more she loves all the characters within the book. The illustrations are fantastic as with all Julia Donaldson books, which allows my daughter to really engage with the book. This is a book that I also enjoy reading, one that I believe that would appeal to both young and old.

This book is about a woodland mouse who manages to escape being eaten by its predators telling them that an imaginary monster is going to appear any minute. As it’s an imaginary monster the mouse does not expect the monster to really show up , so when it does make an appearance the mouse has to convince the Gruffalo he is so scary and it would be a big mistake if he does eat him.This book is a read along rhyme with colourful pictures which I think would be great for early years and key stage 1

The kind of book you can read aloud for multiple purposes in the kindergarten classroom. Read aloud just to enjoy, but then also to discuss questions like, "How did the mouse trick the creatures in the story? Why did he do this?" and "How do the illustrations reveal the responses or feelings of the characters? What makes you think so?" or "How can our imagination deceive us?" You can introduce vocabulary like sneaky, sly, shrewd, calculating or easily deceived or gullible. You can play with rhyming language. "Which word rhymes with black? Orange or back?" Lots of possibilities!!!

Well, this is the first time of me reading The Gruffalo. I bought it to use during my English classes. One of the little girls needs to do some reading exercises and I wanted something fun.I love Scheffler's art but I don't like this new red cover. I think the poor Gruffalo can't stand out on a red background. The story's so nice, though. I've also bought Room on the Broom but I haven't read it yet.

Such a lovely modern children's book. Each month at my work a few companies come in with a book box with a random assortment of items in them (so bloody tempting, I've already spent £20 in the last fortnight). This is in one of them at the moment and so far, I've read it twice and I love it, so much so that I've ordered a copy for a friend's young child to have.The illustration's are fantastic as well.

The Gruffalo is the story of a clever little mouse who outwits the hungry animals of the woods: a fox, an owl, a snake, and the Gruffalo himself! I'm not sure how I managed to miss this classic, but I'm so glad the we've found it now. The story is told in rhyme, so it's fun to read aloud, and it holds the attention of both my toddler and my preschooler.  The movie based on the story is nothing short of magical. Highly recommended!

Love this clever, spunky mouse! He invents a ferocious creature to scare away the other animals in the woods that want to eat him. Then he discovers that his imaginary creature is real, and wants to eat the mouse too. So the courageous mouse outsmarts the Gruffalo.Julia Donaldson makes this seem so easy; her text just rolls out of your mouth effortlessly, making this book the perfect read-aloud.

An intrepid little rhyming mouse sets out on a walk in the forest. As he encounters scary beasties, he uses his wits to scare them away with tales of the ferocious Gruffalo. When he finally meets the Gruffalo himself, our little mouse keeps his wits about him and uses his traditional enemies to scare the new one away. Very cute, very inventive, and very recommended.

[Short and quick review from memory before I re-read and re-review at a later date:Ooooh-only two stars? I mean... why? It's a great book. Not her best (STICK MAN) but not her worst, either (THAT SHIT ONE I DONT REMEMBER THE NAME OF). Maybe it was just too simple... maybe. It had rhymes though D:]

What I personally loved about this book was the vivid illustrations accompanying the story. I loved the way the little mouse was able to overcome danger by out-smarting the larger characters. From a classroom setting I believe this story carries an important message. It doesn’t matter what size you are, what matters, is having self-belief and utilizing your intelligences.

The mouse goes on search for a Gruffalo and finds some other animals on his way as he serches for the gruffalo. But what happens when he finds the gruffalo? This is another great book for cross curriculum links as I have seen in practice. This links to describing word activities, role play, creativity pictures and many more.

This book is about a mouse that goes through the woods, where a fox saw the mouse and wanted to eat it. The story begins showing how clever the mouse is and how he outwits scary enemies. There are many rhyming words with colorful and imaginative illustrations.The story amuses all readers and gives them the message that the most scary monsters are not as scary as they seem.

In my experience, children love finding out what a Gruffalo is every time. This book is really easy to read with a flowing rhythm to the words and great rhymes. Repetitive for the children, which they love, I would highly recommend this book for any child. The wit and courage of the little mouse were inspirational!

- So cute- Illustrations are really bright and fun- The story is so clever- It's a really funny, cute storyMy thoughts:The biggest thing to fear is the Gruffalo. And the Gruffalo does not exist. So there's nothing to fear. I love how this can relate to our own anxieties and worries.

The story is nice. The drawings are cute. Sadly they do not get as good as the animated movie.Now, obviously the movie wouldn't be without this book. Yet it is so much better. And not only the first class acting, but the story is expanded. Now there is a point to the mouse's trip. And the succession from scene to scene is much smoother. Everything is better in the movie.

A fantastic book to read with a KS1 class, we had Julia Donaldson Books as our class topic in a year 1 class so we started with the Gruffalo. It was very interesting finding out it is based off an old Chinese Proverb. The children all engaged well with the story and Axel Scheffler provided fantastic illustration. Very simple and easy to read, perfect picture book for KS1.

Absolutely adorable! Read it aloud to my son and he kind of associated the Gruffalo to the 'wild thigs' in Where the Wild Things Are . . .which is not bad at all. I loved the 'wild things' for the wild things they did and I love the Gruffalo too!

I love this book. I read it to my children often and although now they know the story, they still love choosing this book to be read to them. It is definitely a family favourite as is some of Julia Donaldson's other books, but this is one I would recommend to read.

I adore this story! The rhythm of the story marries well with the illustration. I loved reading it to my daughter and playing with each character's voice. Definitely a fun read out loud book. The animated film is also dear ❤️

The Gruffalo is one of my favourite children's books & to have it in my local dialect makes me very happy (although there was a few Doric words I didn't know). Will definitely be reading this to any future children.

I thoroughly recommend checking out Olly Heaths youtube narration of this, his voice of the Gruffalo screaming 'GRUFFALO CRUMBLE' is worth it. Kinda disturbing how much my son relates to the Gruffalo though, better not read too much into that.

I wasn't sure whether to count this as a book read but I had to read it for my university Children's Literature class so I figured it counted!I love the story, its such a short and funny book and I love the illustrations. I am really excited about analysing it in class!

Reading Challenge 3- book where animal is main character.Good book with great images included. I liked the way that this can be used with a class to show that we shouldn't always judge a book by it's cover and that we should expect the unexpected.
Lol, cute.
It's especially amazing when read by Doug!!
Cute story...cool illustrations. I could see, however, how The Gruffalo could get annoying upon repeated readings.
Being smart is the best super-power ever!
Fantastic story, amazing illustrations. An all-time classic of children's literature.
A smashin' wee read aboot a sleekit wee moose that ootwits a tod, a hoolet an' a gruffalo. Great tae see this in Scots :-)
All I can say is: I'm glad the Gruffalo decided to have a kid, cause I've read this one so many times to the kids now. *chuckles* Great children's book.
amazing incredible and funny
A fun twist on a great story, but it really does take a bit of practice to be able to read it out loud. It would be nice to see more books written in Scots.It was braw :)
the illustrations, the story, the writing... I love everything about this bookcan't wait until I have kids of my own to read this book to
I love that tricky mouse!! :)
my little boy really enjoyed it.
I found this on a list of recommended books for 2-year-olds, but my son is terrified of the Gruffalo and I have to agree that he's frightening. Hopefully he'll enjoy this more when he gets older.
and the book was good
This is 2yo Whit's newest, favorite book!!! ~so cute~
This book is really fun and clever. The artwork is well done and overall this is a great book for reading out loud.
I have to give this book 5 stars or else my two year old will never forgive me. This is the house favorite of my daughters books.
The two year old and the five year old are both instantly obsessed with this book. Fun pictures and great rhyming!
TO READ: During Toddler Time and Preschool Play.
A great book for all ages, with the didactic message of wits overcoming bigger, stronger and scarier people (or animals I suppose in this case) than yourself.
Read this book to my son, and then read it to my Gr. 7 class when discussing adaptations. Both my 4- year old and the Gr. 7’s enjoyed it (but for different reasons).
Everyones favourite! All children love the gruffulo and even older children will join in with the story.
This story was really cute.
I didn't grow up with this lovely book, but I do love the illustrations and the cadence of the words. Great overall.
I have never read this book before this year! I've been missing out. The rhymes are lit, the story's tight, and the ending is so worth the wait. Love and cherish this book forever.
My daughters favourite book by Julia Donaldson.
An all time classic in my household! My younger siblings love this book (and i do too, it’s just so cute!) It’s another staple bedtime story in our house, and a definite family favorite.
Read by Michelle Obama on FB 4/20/20

One of my favourite books as a child, I’ve always loved it! There is a lot of repetition in this book making it perfect for younger children as they could join in with phrases such as ‘There’s no such thing as a Gruffalo?’. The story also follows a rhyming pattern which makes it flow really nicely. There is a clear pattern of the mouse meeting three animals alone then meeting the same three animals with the Gruffalo. This could lead to opportunities for prediction from the children. The description of the Gruffalo would also be good to use when learning about descriptive writing, children could use this as a template to create their own descriptions of a creature they invent. I would use this book as a read aloud story with KS1 children.

This book was one of my favourite read-aloud books as a child, and is still one of my favourite read-aloud books now. The repetition in the language invites children to join in with the story making it very interactive. This language would also be good for EAL children, as they can understand and repeat a familiar pattern of language. You could plan a whole scheme of work around this book where the children create their own Gruffalo from clay in art, and write about the adventure in English. The illustrations accompany the beautifully simple rhyming language which helps the book flow as a read aloud story.

text-to-world connection This story is a great example of perception and perspective. A trickster type main character who uses his wit in lieu of big muscles or a scary outward appearance to ward off predators. We sometimes have to be creative navigating social situations without using the obvious aggressions or confrontations one would expect in precarious situations. The mouse is small, but confident in his ability to survive, and uses his way of thinking, to sway others into believing in his survival as well. Charismatic is another word to describe that type of convincing behavior. Much like a politician. When put under pressure to survive, being able to convince someone else that you are capable and putting their own fears into play is not only strategic, but in this case, detrimental to his life span, and forest credit! Love this classic book.

This was included in the learning materials for French kids who can't go to school due to quarantine. The previous material is apparently useful as I learned enough vocab beforehand to understand this book without needing to refer to the dictionary so much.Mice has always been smart creatures in fables and this one doesn't disappoint.

A clever mouse is met in the woods by an owl, snake and fox. The mouse tells each animal, describing a strange and formidable creature, The Gruffalo. The Gruffalo may or may not exist. What would happen if it was real? Find out in this rhyming story. The book could be a perfect read-aloud even without pictures. Lastly, it dares readers to ask...is the gruffalo real?

Fun to read, allows your child to try to figure out complex motivations (i.e., why let the Gruffalo think that the animals are scared of the mouse, not the Gruffalo?). The story also has predictable repetition so kids can chime in at certain points in the story.[based on the version that came from Dolly Parton's Imagination Library. this means that the story is exactly the same as any other, but there are suggested reading tips for parents on the back inside flap]
A great book for developing a love of fantasy and a well loved book for most children - it adds a sense of community to the child to know they're reading the same book as the majority of the country.

Clever mouse. The more picture books I read, the more I realize that it is REALLY hard to create a rhyming one that doesn't sound forced and awkward. The Gruffalo is one of the good ones. And although it is called The Gruffalo, the mouse id really the star of the show.

Such a wily little mouse. The story is told in rhyme and the reader will get a laugh over how good he looks to the creatures in the woods. The illustrations bring to mind the familiar book, Where the Wild Things Are, written and illustrated by Maurice Sendak. Imaginative and lots of fun.

The Gruffalo is a classic book and one of my favourites. It’s a great book for Year 2 in which the mouse uses his wit to outsmart the big and scary Gruffalo. The mouse demonstrates that size does not matter and avoids being eaten by all the other, and bigger, animals in the forest. It’s a great book for an older age range due to the use of descriptive language in which all the animals are described within the book.

Grandsons and I adore this book for its rollicking metre, expressive words and the twist at the end. A classic! There should be a Goodreads category for books that are reread dozens, even hundreds of times.
Wonderful!
Such an amazing book! My 5yr old nephew was given this the first day of school and it was a delight to read for him and to him. Rating: GLanguage: no bad stuffRecommend: Yes!
Heard of this one for ages, but never read it. A funny little tale of the mouse who meets the gruffalo on his walk.
Carwyn really enjoys the Gruffalo. He loves to hear 👂 the story every night at most and enjoys reciting the rhymes.
I like this book because the mouse was very clever and he tricked the Gruffalo and the other animals in this book.
A mouse creates a made up creature, the Gruffalo, as he walks through the forest. He is surprised when he actually meets one. A good read aloud book because of the rhyme scheme.
Read this adorable story to my nephew and I adored it: it's a delight reading it to the little ones!
A mouse finds a way to scare off all of his predators by creating the oh so scary Gruffalo! This is such a fun story! One of our favorites!
The Gruffalo is everything a read aloud should be. It is the one picture book my fourth and fifth graders beg me to read each year, and that's high praise, indeed.
Cute, smart, short :)
Something about my daughter constantly saying 'you go ahead and I'll follow after' in every day life. The little patterns that break out of great children's books and linger.
We're all different and unique. A nice book that talks about using each other's strengths to cover our own weaknesses.
WOW!!I didn't think I would enjoy this as much as I did!!It was Short and engaging with great illustrations.
Wonderful book for kids. The story is simple for them to follow but good. The art is excellent. Great fun.
Great informative book 10/10 amazing plot line raised me fed me saved me
The favourite book of my kids. About smart little brown mouse and another fairy tale creature Gruffalo
my favourite book ever
I love this cute little story. It is also great on audio. Less than 10 minutes on read time.

At the end of the book It doesn’t make any sense why would the gruffalo be scared if a mouse said “my favourite food is gruffalo pie? Because how is a mouse supposed to eat something 10 times the size of you?
Only giving 5 stars because of how well Michelle Obama read it on PBS
Very cute story with an engaging rhyme and repetition.
Read this one with the kids. Cute and original.
This is one of the books bought for the little library. So super funny I will say that mouse is very sneaky lol. a book you and the kiddos in your life will love for sure. :)
Funny and thought-provoking. My 3 year old recites the hole story by heart.
A modern clever critter tale

Read again and again with the 4 yo, who almost has it memorized. She loved saying "the three things" when the mouse describes the Gruffalo, and to be tickled when she reads "he has purple prickles all over his back!"

The book follows a mouse who goes on a walk through the forest, inventing a tale of a terrible creature called The Gruffalo to scare the other animals he meets. But what will the mouse do when he comes face to face with the real Gruffalo? I have loved this book since I was a child and it gives an important lesson not to judge a book by its cover.

Such a brilliant book. My baby and I can't get enough. The rhythm and story is so satisfying and there's a lot to unpack with perception and the quick thinking mouse. Obsessed and happy 20 year anniversary!

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson is an addictive and attention grabbing children’s book aimed at children from the ages of 3 to 6. It is an expressive story about a clever little mouse travelling through the deep dark woods meeting a fox, an owl and a snake along the way. The only problem is they want to, potentially, eat him. However, the quick thinking mouse, tells a tale of a scary fictional beast called the 'Gruffalo' to get out of the tricky situations. A dramatic twist in the story shows how the mouse ends up confronting the fictional beast later, who is actually real and wants to eat the little mouse too. The double twist in the story then arises when the quick witted mouse tactically escapes the ‘Gruffalo' by devising another tale by which he successfully outsmarts the beast.I can read this to my own children (aged 3 and 7) many times and they are absorbed by its rhyming couplets and repetition which allows story telling to flow brilliantly. The book has vibrant illustrations by Axel Scheffler which are light hearted yet good enough to display and help children visualise the scary ‘Gruffalo’ before his grand appearance. The pictures can help children of all abilities comprehend and enjoy the story. My three year old can describe the ‘Gruffalo’ through the pictures, so story telling becomes very interactive.This book can be used in many ways to form creative lessons especially in reception and year 1 classes. The story can be told in segments with activities based around each theme forming discussions to get the children involved. In literacy children can identify rhyming words and create their own rhymes and in creative writing children can brainstorm ideas to form versions of a scary imaginary character using synonyms of the words used to describe the ‘Gruffalo’ in the book. Also, through improvisation and role-play children can use the different characters to construct a short play and bring the story to life. It can also be incorporated into science, integrated into the learning of food chains, habitats and adaptations of animals. Art lessons benefit greatly using this book as of its excellent descriptions of the animals and brilliant illustrations. Also, on a moral level it also can be used to convey the importance of telling the truth and how a little fib like the mouse told, which although did get the mouse out of trouble from being eaten by predators, did eventually land him to confront the real beast in the end.Overall, story telling truly comes to life with this admirable book and children discover how the mouse becomes the hero of the story, and his innocent betrayal of the others animals puts him in and out of inconvenient situations. The Gruffalo is fun to read, dynamic and catchy and therefore it is a must have in every classroom.

Nobody's as gruff as a gruffalo.It's another story where the main character is a "trickster," which basically means they lie a bunch. It's not bad, especially because the main character is lying to save their own life. There's a mouse, and a fox sees the mouse and implies that he's going to eat him. The mouse says, 'No, I'm going to wait for my friend The Gruffalo, who's scary and gigantic and likes to eat foxes.' The fox leaves in fear, and the mouse says to himself, "Silly old Fox! Doesn't he know? There's no such thing as a Gruffalo!" The mouse then encounters an owl and a snake, using the same story on them, getting more descriptive about the imaginary monster. Suddenly, he encounters a Gruffalo, exactly as he had described. Which is a rather unusual twist for a trickster tale. The Gruffalo threatens to eat the mouse, but the mouse shows the Gruffalo that the fox, owl, and snake are all afraid of the two of them (obviously to the reader, because they are afraid of the Gruffalo, not the mouse, but the Gruffalo interprets it as them being afraid of the mouse), and then the mouse threatens to eat the Gruffalo, who leaves in fear. The end.Like I said, it's a really unusual twist to have the thing that a character is explicitly, intentionally lying about, turn out to be true. Of course, as in most "trickster tales", it relies on the "tricked" characters being complete idiots. For me, this doesn't paint the trickster as clever or intelligent, just lucky and dishonest. If the mouse wasn't trying to save his own life, this would have a bad message, but as it is, it's just middle-of-the-road. It's perfectly reasonable to lie to somebody to save your own life.The rhymes are actually pretty good. The meter is good, nothing feels forced, and it seems like it would work well being read aloud. And the descriptions of The Gruffalo are interesting. I guess people enjoy seeing others get tricked. Of course, as is the case in similar stories with anthropomorphic animals, you have the moral quandary of intelligent animals eating other intelligent animals. If they were all humans instead of animals, this whole thing would be highly disturbing, but they're not, so it's not. So I guess it's okay for a talking fox to eat a talking mouse. I know it's a convention we're pretty used to by now, but that doesn't mean it isn't weird.Message: People who try to hurt you are stupid, and will fall for obvious tricks.For more children's book reviews, see my website at http://www.drttmk.com.

This was a very good book for shared reading, because it involves a lot of prediction. The children can join in the book themselves, because even if they can't read it, they can predict what is going to come next. It is also a funny book that can be enjoyed by both children and adults. It can be used for many other activities, such as drawing the Gruffalo or creating a role-play with the various animals.This book has rhythmic language, which is suitable to being read aloud. By having a good rhythm, more intonation and emotion can be put into the language, which helps to increase the children's interest in the story.The language is also repetitive. At the end of each meeting with an animal, the mouse says: "Silly old (animal's name)! Doesn't he know, there's no such thing as a Gruffalo?" This is beneficial for shared reading, because the children join in with the story, as they can predict what is going to happen next. The language also follows the same sentence structure: an animal meets the mouse; the animal tries to eat him; the mouse explains why he can't be eaten because he is meeting with the Gruffalo; the mouse describes the Gruffalo and says that his favourite food is the animal he's talking to; the animal runs away. This repetitiveness encourages prediction and response, as the children are more able to understand the story.There are also many excellent illustrations in the storybook that support the text. For example, each time the mouse describes the Gruffalo; we just see the features that he is describing, not the whole Gruffalo. This encourages the children to use their imagination to guess what the Gruffalo could look like and each time they receive more clues.

Summary:The Gruffalo is about a mouse who encounters multiple predators and every time he meets one he describes new details about his friend the Gruffalo. Eventually, the mouse encounters a real Gruffalo that matches his description. To keep from being eaten, he tells the Gruffalo he is the most feared in the forest and proves it to him by reencountering all the predators from earlier. As he encounters each one, they all scatter because the mouse had told them that they were the Gruffalo's favorite meal. After seeing all the predators scatter, the Gruffalo becomes scared of the mouse and runs away.Evaluation:This is a good story about how brains and cunningness can protect even the smallest of creatures. The mouse proves this by describing something that the predators would be afraid so that he would not be eaten. Each time he added another detail and told the predator that they were the creatures favorite meal. Then when the mouse was encountered by his described creature, he used his earlier lie to save him from being eaten by the creature. To come up with lies on the spot takes brains and cunningness.Teacher Tip:As a teacher, I would use this story to talk about visualization and descriptions. The lesson would begin with me reading the story and having the students draw their own Gruffalo based on the description. Then I would show the students what the illustrations show what a Gruffalo looks like. This would lead to a discussion about how they want to add enough detail to their own writing. I would follow this by giving the students a picture of an odd looking creature and have them write a description of the creature. Then the students would read it to the class and see if anyone could draw exactly what he or she was describing.

The Gruffalo is a fun rhyming story about a mouse and the big gruffalo. The mouse was on his way to see the gruffalo when he was stopped by the fox. The fox asks what the gruffalo was and the mouse described him as a big monster with large tusks, big bear claws, and terrible teeth. The mouse tells the fox that the gruffalo eats foxes and the fox ran away. But, there is no such thing as a gruffalo. The mouse then ran into the owl who tried to eat the mouse. The mouse told him he was on his way to see the gruffalo who has knobby knees, turned out toes, and a poisonous wart on his nose. The mouse told the owl that the gruffalo's favorite food is owl and the owl flies away. The mouse then runs into a snake and the mouse tells him the same thing that he is going to meet the gruffalo. The mouse describes the gruffalo with having orange eyes, a black tongue, with purple prickles all over his back. But, little does the snake know the gruffalo isn't real. Once the snake learns that the gruffalo eats snakes, he slithers away. As the mouse continues on in the forest, he runs into the real gruffalo. The gruffalo tries to eat the mouse but he said wait and said that he was the scariest animal in the forest. He told the gruffalo to follow behind him and he would prove his scariness. The mouse and the gruffalo pass the snake, owl, and fox who run in fear from the gruffalo following behind the mouse. The mouse then tells the gruffalo that his favorite food was gruffalo crumble and the gruffalo ran away scared. The mouse sat in peace and ate his nuts. This is a fun story for kids to enjoy with their imagination. Describing the gruffalo allows students imagination to run free and picture what the gruffalo actually looks like before he is revealed in the book.

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson is based on a Chinese folktale. As the story goes, a tiger wanted, more than anything to become human. In order for him to make his wish come true, he had to eat three children. He finally met his match when he came upon the third child. Donaldson does a wonderful job recreating the folktale. Mouse can be credited with giving Gruffalo the big scary creature persona. It was absolutely necessary to keep himself from being someone else's meal as he walked through the deep dark wood. His plan was working perfectly until he, unexpectedly, met up with the Gruffalo. Could Mouse's wit save him?The Gruffalo is a terrific book filled with of vivid descriptions, rhymes, repetition, and predictability. I would recommend it for K-3 and possibly as a mentor text for upper elementary. The big scary creature is not quite gruesome enough to scare the little ones and the colorful description of him, that Donaldson provides, may be an inspiration for older kids and their writing. This story could be tied into a science curriculum. Students could create their own creature, then describe the creature’s habitat, prey, predators, and adaptations. Another science related activity, would be to have the students to create a food chain, as an extension to the story. This book would also make a good choice for a choral read, reader’s theater activity or a "moral of the story" discussion for the primary grades.

We love this book! It’s just so clever and fun, and the illustrations are great. I like the cleverness of the mouse tricking the other creatures one by one. I like how the text goes from fox to owl to snake, then Gruffalo, then back in reverse order (snake, owl, fox). Certain phrases are repeated often, too. The repetitions are great for little readers. Asher has parts of this book memorized as a result, and you never know when you’re going to hear a little “Oh help! Oh no! It’s a Gruffalo!” in his playing.As usual, I’m not super thrilled that every single creature in the book is male. Five total creatures and not one could be female?Also, other parents have complained that this book encourages lying. I’m not as solidly against lying as most people are, though — for one thing, I think it’s an unrealistic place to plant my flag and don’t want to get caught up in enforcing it; for another, lying at a young age is correlated with intelligence; and finally and especially, the power and control aspect of telling others not to lie troubles me (awfully convenient for those in authority). And, importantly, the story doesn’t work without it. This mouse has to be shrewd to survive! So that never even occurred to me as a concern with this book until it was pointed out, but if that’s a big deal in your moral code, this might not be the book for you.Detailed review on the Over-Analyzing Children's Books blog at https://o-acb.com/2018/08/06/review-t...__

“A mouse took a stroll through the deep dark wood… but what happens when he meets a hungry gruffalo?”This story follows the journey of a very smart mouse who manages to trick the scary creatures she faces but can she trick a gruffalo?The Gruffalo is a wonderful way to introduce key stage 1 to the key features of an adventure story and the excitement of story mountains. It is also a great way to teach what a noun and adjective are, the differences between them and how we can make word choices to manipulate our reader. Its rhyme and repetition makes it a brilliant book to read aloud. Its rhyme and repetition also makes it easy to recite, ideal for extended pieces of writing in year 1.

The Gruffalo by Julia Donaldson is just a wonderfully written, beautifully illustrated book which is now one of my firm favourites! I love the descriptions of the characters and the way it has been written I think is very clever. Using passages of text full of description allows one to fully immerse themselves in the imagination of these rather interesting characters. The sly little mouse really gives you an insight into what he might be like. Using excellent passages such as 'through the deep dark woods does little mouse go, announcing his meeting with the fierce gruffalo'. Just magical!Wonderfully captivating, and beautifully illustrated - the pictures have made this into an incredibly successful franchise which is adored by children - my nephew being one throughout. He loves sitting on my knee laughing like a drain in utter enjoyment as the story unfolds, pointing at the pictures and desperately waiting to turn the next page and finds out what happens next. The fact that he has read it now over 40 times should indicate just how much he does love it, but it always makes me smile reading it to him! The language used and repetitive nature of the text makes it a firm favourite - and the opportunities for further extention activities either at home or in the classroom are endless.Just a delight to read, and if you haven't read it yet - you are definitely missing out!!

The Gruffalo is a story about a mouse going through the woods and all these animals come up trying to convince the mouse to come to their house so the animal can eat him. The mouse makes up a story about a gruffalo and how he likes to eat the animal the mouse is talking to. The animals scare away until the mouse runs in to a real gruffalo! He tells the gruffalo that he is the most scary of them all and to follow him through the woods to see. The animals all scurry away because their scared of the gruffalo so the gruffalo thinks the mouse is really scary and runs off. The Gruffalo's theme would be to not judge a book by its cover. Everyone thought the gruffalo was scary when he turned out to be afraid of the mouse. This is a great example of how being smart can really get you places in life. When I read this book I found myself smiling because the mouse was so smart. He kept getting harassed and all he wanted was a nice stroll through the woods. He was very smart and it worked in his favor. I would recommend this book because it is fun and it rhymes. This is perfect for children because it will keep them entertained. It would also be a good book to be able to ask questions along the way to keep the reader engaged like "Why do you think he is doing this?" or "What do you think is going to happen?"

I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. The rhyming text lends itself perfectly to being read aloud and would therefore be a brilliant book to use as a shared read. The repetition of certain phrases throughout the book helps children to feel at ease and gives them the chance to get involved. The book uses humour cleverly to engage its reader and children will love phrases such as "scrambled snake" and "gruffalo crumble".Alongside Scheffler's wonderfully detailed illustrations, Donaldson's brilliant descriptions help to bring the text to life. The book could be used to help children to think about character descriptions and effective use of adjectives. Children could have a go at writing their own descriptive pieces, inventing their own versions of the gruffalo. They could also try to spot the many different language devices used by Donaldson in the text, for example alliteration ("deep dark wood").This book promotes the power of intelligence and it's wonderful to see the tiny mouse using wit to overcome all of the other creatures in the wood.Overall I see this text as a fantastic one to share with children. Readers of all ages will find themselves enthralled with the plight of the little mouse and the book can be adapted to be used in many different ways.

This book was a new release when I was young, and it was one of my most treasured books growing up. It is a really clever story and written so well. It has fantastic flow with simple rhymes that become very memorable e.g. "terrible tusks, and terrible claws, and terrible teeth in its terrible jaw". The story is an instant classic, children will be reading this for generations to come. Each child frightened, intrigued and excited by the gruffalo, and in addition captivated by the mouse. What is really special about this book is it inspires children to use their imagination, just as the mouse did. In relation to teaching: - I recommend this book be taught/read to KS1 as the narrative, especially the ending could be tricky for EYFS to understand, and could potentially frighten them. - This story is so popular it would encourage participation is english based activites e.g. write your own encounter of the mouse meeting another creature, and describing the gruffalo differently. - The story has a range of characters, could be used to introduce children to character emotions e.g. "the mouse felt smug when he tricked the fox". - This story is perfect for creative activities across the curriculum, e.g. create your own imaginary creature like the mouse created a gruffalo.

While strolling the forest, a little mouse encounters different predators, including a fox, an owl, and a snake, who invite the mouse back to their homes for a meal. The little mouse, however, is clever, and tells each of the animals that he is on his way to meet a Gruffalo, and begins to describe the scary aspects of the Gruffalo, such as his tusks, teeth, and warts, which scares the animals away. Because of his clever thinking, the mouse is able to continue his stroll in the forest.The illustrations and the text in the book follow a similar pattern with one another and tell the story in a consistent manner. The text consists of rhyming and follows the same structure throughout. Similarly, the illustrations follow the same format, especially in the beginning, showing full and half pages of illustrations, alternatively. When the mouse describes certain features of the Gruffalo, the illustrator includes three circles on the page which highlight those specific features that the mouse is describing. The illustrations are sure to captivate any audience with its realistic, but simplified version of each of the animals and the background of the forest.

Summary: A mouse is walking through the forest and runs into different animals along the way. As he goes he describes a Gruffalo to scare them away from him. He adds more details as the story progresses, and eventually he runs into a real Gruffalo. Now the mouse needs a way to make the Gruffalo scared of him. The mouse has the Gruffalo follow him back through the woods and makes him think the mouse is really the one scaring the other animals away.Evaluation: This is a fun book! I like how detail is added throughout the plot of the story. You aren’t really expecting the plot twist which makes the story more engaging. I really like that this book was also made into a short film which could even further enhance the visualization teaching idea I suggested.Teaching Idea: I would use this book to teach about visualization. Students would simply listen to the book as the Gruffalo was being described and draw what they were visualizing. I would let them share their drawings with each other and discuss similarities and differences. Then, I would read the book again while showing the pictures. We would discuss how an author’s words can shape our visualization.
