When the other animals ask the mouse why he cannot spend time with them, he explains that he is meeting the Gruffalo, a monster, in turn scaring away all the other animals. When the mouse meets with the Gruffalo, the gruffalo says the mouse would taste really good on toast. The mouse explains he is not good, in fact everyone in the woods is scared of him. Scared from the descriptions the mouse has shared about the Gruffalo, the animal friends run away as they pass by in the forest. Finally, the mouse explains that he is hungry for some gruffalo crumble, which then scares the Gruffalo away.The theme of this book is fear and the smaller person overcoming larger obstacles. I really enjoyed the illustrations. They carry over from one page to another, allowing for familiarity, and they are incredibly detailed and depict more than the written description, allowing readers to apply their imagination. I think in general, the story line is nothing overly exciting, yet it is nice to see that the smallest character, the mouse, is able to overcome obstacles put in place by the bigger characters.

Ah, so now we get it. Some series of books are just meant to be read in order. We read The Gruffalo's Child first, not knowing at first that it was in a series of books. And we liked it, but it felt like we were missing out on something. So we borrowed this book and it all became so clear to us. And funny, too! We loved the story, with it's predictable storyline, colorful illustrations and rhyming narrative. The sing-song rhythm is fun to read aloud and we really enjoyed reading this book together.This book was featured as one of the selections for the September 2019: Celebrating Julia Donaldson discussion at the Picture-Book Club in the Children's Books group here at Goodreads.

The Gruffalo is a story of a made up creature which a clever mouse creates in order to avoid his predators in the wood. This picture books has full page illustrations and is aimed at young children ranging from nursery to KS1. The language is very repetitive and allows the child to join in with the familiar phrases. The story is written in rhyme and creates the feel of a journey when read. The story shows how quick thinking allows a a problem to be overcome. The story allows a resolution to come about when the mouse is proven to be as scary as he claims and then finally gets his tea he has been talking about. The descriptions of the Gruffalo are given in detail which allows the child to build up a picture of the Gruffalo before he is revealed, this might be a good way of ensuring the child is not scared of the monster as they are familiar with his features. The book could be used in KS2 to show how 'white lies' are used and the need for them. Also this book would provide for good descriptive writing and 'hot seating' opportunities for older (KS2) childen.

Being the lowest on the food chain requires you to get creative and clever to prevent from getting eaten! This book is about a mouse who escapes getting eaten by a fox, owl and snake by tricking them into thinking he is going to have a feast with a Gruffalo, a fictitious character that enjoys eating roasted fox, owl ice cream and scrambled snake. Much to his dismay, mouse encounters the very character that he thought he made up! When he realizes the Gruffalo wants to eat him too, he once again, escapes getting eaten though clever trickery. He convinces the Gruffalo to follow him through the wood to show that he is the most feared animal in the wood, when in fact, it is the Gruffalo the animals fear. After all the predators scramble, the mouse decides that he is hungry and threatens to eat the Gruffalo. The Gruffalo darts into the woods, leaving the mouse to enjoy a peaceful meal alone, safe and sound.

The Gruffalo was published in 1999 and is a story about a mouse's journey through the woods and its encounters with other animals (or creatures). The little mouse comes across many dangerous animals that plan to eat the mouse, but its clever thinking manipulates these animals into thinking that his make-belief friend, the Gruffalo, just so happens to be the scariest of them all, and this clever technique succeeds in scaring of these dangerous animals. Then later on in the story, to the mouse's surprise, a real-life Gruffalo appears. This story is great or children of all ages due to its simplistic level of text, the effective use of continuous rhyme and its eye-catching illustrations to further uphold engagement. To this day, the Gruffalo still excites me when reading and it is a book that I believe anyone would enjoy reading regardless of the target audience being aimed at children.

I bought this because I was impressed by Room on the Broom by the same authorial team. The illustration style is similar (and not my favorite of the many children's books we have, but not bad by any means). Like Room on the Broom, the rhymes here are quick and fluid, well-suited to reading aloud, but with more impressive vocabulary and a more complex story than the average board-book fare. Here, the story features a mouse who terrifies would-be predators with tales of a beast called a gruffalo. When he finds out that the gruffalo is real and none too friendly, he uses his wits to escape the purple-spiked peril. The book's repetitive structure appeals to babies but isn't tiresome for the adults who have to read to them. Not saying it deserves a Pulitzer, but it's a bright spot in an often underwhelming field.

This one is a classic and of course, I had to say a few things about it. I remember when I was younger I got this read to me everywhere; preschool, school... home. And honestly, the story was never a favorite of mine. The message in the story never really meant much to as a child. The story is about a mouse walking through a forest full of creatures that want to eat him. It sounds terrifying already I know, but the smart mouse has a plan, he has a brain. He tells each of his predators that he is meeting a Gruffalo for lunch, each time explaining how much Gruffalo love to eat 'insert predator'. This, of course, scares away the fox, the owl, and the snake, but what will they mouse tell the Gruffalo when he meets him? How do I not spoil a kids book? Overall the art in this book always caught my attention as a kid with the vid colors and characters within the forest.

An easily understood storyline, even for quite young children, and simply wonderful to read aloud with its swinging rhythm and rhyming verses - one of those books I always enjoy reading - even half a dozen times in an afternoon. Julia Donaldson seems to get the adult/child balance right with just about every book. I say 'just about' because I get a bit choked up reading The Singing Mermaid and Sugarlump and the Unicorn and I'd really prefer not to, but the grandchildren love nearly all of her books I've read to them so far.

KS1- Year 1 and 2.English: Investigate the rhyming in the book. Which words rhyme? Can you think of other words that rhyme with those? The story uses lots of different types of punctuation. Look at each type of punctuation and explain why it has been used. -Perhaps link to poetry. Use to illustrate the idea that not everything has to rhyme all of the time but also that stories can have elements that rhyme. Drama - role play, freeze frames and hot heating could be of good use for this story.Science: Write a report about an imaginary creature. What does it eat? Where does it live? How is it adapted to live in that place? Create a food chain using the animals in the story and shown in the pictures.

The story of a mouse's walk through the woods unfolds in two phases; in both, the mouse uses cunning to evade danger. On his way the mouse encounters several dangerous animals (a fox, an owl, and a snake). Each of these animals, clearly intending to eat the mouse, invites him back to their home for a meal. The cunning mouse declines each offer. To dissuade further advances, he tells each animal that he has plans to dine with his friend, a gruffalo, a monster-like hybrid that is half grizzly bear and half buffalo, whose favourite food happens to be the relevant animal, and describes the features of the gruffalo's monstrous anatomy. Frightened that the gruffalo might eat it, each animal flees.

The book is a story about a mouse that is taking a hike through the forest. He runs into animals that are a lot bigger than he is and very intimidating as well. The mouse gets out of eating with these animals by making up a "friend" that is a Gruffalo. This book was super cute and had imagination. I loved that it shows that the mouse had a toughness to him to avoid being eaten by the bigger animals and scared them off by his "made" up friend. I would use this book in my classroom to introduce rhyming words. I would have the students pair up with classmates and write a short story with rhyming words and then read it to the class. I would also talk about courage and not being scared when faced with bigger challenges.

A mouse is taking a stroll through the deep, dark wood of a European forest when, much like Maurice Sendak’s quartet of wild things, along comes a hungry fox, then an owl, and then a snake. The mouse is good enough to eat, but smart enough to know this, so he invents . . . the gruffalo! As Mouse explains, the gruffalo is a creature “with terrible claws, and terrible tusks in its terrible jaws, and knobbly knees and turned-out toes, and a poisonous wart at the end of its nose.” The gullible fox runs away when Mouse tells him that the gruffalo’s favorite food is roasted fox. “Silly old Fox!” says Mouse, “Doesn’t he know? There’s no such thing as a gruffalo!”

This book has been around for a long time, I remember reading this when I was younger.It is about a mouse who goes on a walk and meets different animals and makes up stories about a so-called 'Gruffalo' and convinces them that he is the scariest and dangerous of them all. To his surprise, he then ends up meeting the Gruffalo that he has been talking about.This book is enjoyed by many young children as they are always eager to discover what is going to happen next and what other animals are in the story. It has a repetitive aspect to it which encourages children to remember parts of the story and participate actively.

A clever mouse tells other frightening animals that he has a friend called a Gruffalo so that they will not eat him. Surprisingly the mouse runs into an actual Gruffalo but again uses a clever technique to persuade the Gruffalo not to eat him.  This story has a great plot. It keeps the reader interested. Because of that, it would be a great story to discuss with students. Students can answer question about characters, the settings, or the major events. Students could also ask questions to teacher as some things are implied and you may have to determine if the Gruffalo is just Mouse’s imagination.

A mouse scares off predators with stories about an imaginary monster called a Gruffalo, but when he meets a real live Gruffalo, he has to think fast to avoid being eaten.This is a variation of the classic tale in which a weaker person defeats a stronger opponent(s) by outwitting him/her/them. It can also be read as a commentary on the power of storytelling. In addition, the story supports the idea that faking confidence can get one through a difficult situation. The rhyming text verges on sing-song at points but will reinforce phonological awareness skills. Disclosure: Dolly Parton was kind enough to send our family this book through her Imagination Library Foundation.

The Gruffalo is my favourite of Julia Donaldson's lovely and fun books for young children. The story is told in rhyming verse and tells the tale of a little brown mouse who takes a walk through the forest and comes up with a rather unique way of keeping himself safe from predators. The little brown mouse tell all the creatures he meets and who have an eye on him as their lunch, that he is meeting a Gruffalo. The Gruffalo is a very scary creatures and all the other creatures of afraid of him. The pictures are delightful and I can still remember the words to this story almost word for word.

I was looking for books to share with my students this next six weeks. This one came from Time magazine's list of top 100 books for children. I read it, found a song for it. and I love it! This is such a neat story. A mouse is walking in the woods and comes upon several predators that want to eat it. However, the clever mouse tells each one he is going to eat with a gruffalo that happens to eat the predators, thus scaring them away. The surprise comes when the mouse actually comes upon the gruffalo that it has been imaging. I can't wait to share this book.

A clever mouse makes up a story about a fearsome monster to scare off the various animals who want to eat him. What a surprise when the mouse meets the monster that he thought he made up. But the clever, clever mouse turns the tables by convincing the Gruffalo that he is the the most feared animal in the forest. This reminds me of Brer Rabbit and his fast talking ways. What I find amazing is that I knew about the Gruffalo's child, but never knew that there was book about THE Gruffalo. Just rounding out my knowledge and enjoying it.

This book I found is a classic children's favourite, which I also read as a young girl. With pictures, as well as easy reading and clear font, it includes rhyming to tell the story of The Gruffalo. I found it fantastic that it included rhyming, something you begin learning within primary school at a young age, whilst it also simply told a story. Through the story being easy to follow, it made rhyming in terms of poetry appear more fun when being creative, rather than what I'd personally associate poetry and rhyming with, which is hard and confusing- for me.

Key Stage 1Really enjoyed this book and children will enjoy it. There are many ways this could be used in the classroom and develop it into may facits.1. Explore the characters i.e Owl, Mouse, Fox, Snake.2. Use it as a drama project with the children acting the book out.3. Look at the characters habitat and their environment.4. Look at how the author has used rhyme to tell the story.5. Buy the Gruffalo as soft toy for the children to use as a mascot / take pictures on days out.

Story - 4Writing Style - 4Illustrations - 4Overall - 4 I love the story of The Gruffalo. I think the mouse is such a great character. The rhyming patterns are brilliant, really good for identifying rhyming words.The different descriptions of the parts of the Gruffalo are also great. I love the progression through the different characters, building up to the ending.A real feel-good out loud read that children just seem to love.

Things aren't always as they seem, and a small stature may prove to be quite wise, as you'll find in the tale of the Gruffalo. A mouse walks through the forest describing the terrible, "Grufflo" to other forest animals... This story is told in rhyme, with a predictable pattern that allows young readers to participate in the reading. My first grade students loved naming the animals in the story and the story ending. This book is great as a read aloud for ages 2-7.

A trickster book! and a good one! This is a book that everyone will enjoy. I love the illustrations and the orginality of the story. I also like that is the type of book with repeated phrases because this allows pre-readers to become active participants in read-aloud time. With these types of books young children enjoy the rhythmic, lyrical patterns, and the ablility to chime in with a phrase that has become familiar to them.

This book smartly takes such a complex topic as deception, impressions of others, and our differences and simplifies it for children making it fable-like and age-appropriate. It uses rhyming words and encourages children to stretch their imaginations throughout the story creating their own image in their minds of what the gruffalo may look like. Lots of divergent questions can be asked throughout the story and it is pretty engaging.

I chose this book to read aloud for storybook showcase because it is my kids' favorite book. I think children enjoy this story because it is full of suspense and irony. It also shows children that appearance does not matter, but rather how you use your mind. The fictitious characters add humor to the story, and the repetitive phrases allow children to predict what happens next. There are also a variety of vocabulary words introduced throughout the story.

My sister and I found this book while at a random toy store in her little town. The whole thing looked interesting so I read it in the store then and there to see if my kids would enjoy it.I fell in love with it right away, and just had to have it for our little collection. My son loved it, but my daughter was too young to remember it very well. This one has a special place on the bookshelf in my heart, that's for sure.

I love this story by Julia Donaldson about a clever mouse navigating his way through the deep dark wood. He outfoxes a fox, owl and a snake by telling them that he is meeting a fierce creature called a Gruffalo. Lo and behold, is the gruffalo actually real? Solid artwork and a fun story for kids.In rarity, as good as this book is, I actually like the film better which is streaming on Netflix. It is excellent.

This was one of my favourite books to read to the littleies when I was working - my Teacher/Librarian role was one of wonder and love. The Gruffalo and The Gruffalo's Child identify what is good and wonderful in Children's literature. Nothing frightening or unpleasant, just wholesome "loose yourself in a book" writing. The pictures are wonderful too. The Gruffalo is a must read and love book for all young children and one their parents and Grandparents will treasure with them.

I'm putting this one on the "come back to" list. A friend told me her son (same age) loves this book, but it was not a hit here. There was a lot of concern out of Lu about the 'monster-ness' of the Gruffalo. He viewed this as a scary book.(April 2019, library book)

Gruffalo was everywhere, so when I spotted a textured version in a book shop, I thought 'thousands (millions?) of people can't be wrong' and bought it quick sharp. My daughter is ambivalent at most, and I just don't get the hype at all. This has mostly remained at the bottom of a large and very dynamic pile, sadly.

Synopsis: In order to get people to leave them alone, a mouse tells them that a scary creature is coming - except that the creature actually exists!Key Words: Nature, Friendships, Food chainsSchool Year Group: Year 1Review: A sweet book that would be very good for introducing adjectives - although could have done with a better ending.

This is one of my favorite kids books! The Snail and the Whale is my ultimate favorite, but this is not far behind. I didn't even realize they were the same author until recently. I guess she just has a style that sings to me. This book is funny and cute. I've read it at campfires and the kids love it. Highly recommend!

My daughter loved this. She's 19-months-old and it was a Christmas present for her. Good present. The clever mouse, the sinister predators and the ultimate monster from the mouse's imagination - all great fun. We love Julia Donaldson's books in our house. This is a good one but not the best I reckon (Charlie Cook's Favourite Book maybe?).

The Gruffalo is one of our very favorites. It is universally loved by all four of our children (and us parents too.) I can’t tell you how many times I’ve been asked through giggles to make roasted fox, owl ice cream, and scrambled snake. It’s a book that should be in every child’s library. The short film adaption is also wonderful.

This is a sort of book I haven't read in a while - where a meek animal preys on the fears of the fear of a large animal to butt off smaller animals. 'Gruffalo' sounds ridiculous as a name, but works as a deceit game - for the mouse and brings down the house, with the lovely words that rhyme all the time.

"The Gruffalo" by Julia Donaldson is the first book from this author I read and I really liked it; my daughter as well.It's witty, funny, easy to read and it rhymes. It is very repetitive which actually annoys me in some of her other books however in this one, maybe because it was the first one and I still remember the 'wow' exclamation I made, I give it 5 stars.

Myself and my Goddaughter loved this story. The illrustrations are incredible. The story was funny and quirky. Love everything to do with this series, the cartoons, the books and of course the ride in Chessington. Will be reading this book again as we both get so much enjoyment from it. Would highly recommend.

Cute rhyming story about a mouse and a gruffalo. This book encourages children to use their imaginations throughout the whole book, keeping them engaged and anticipating the next page.I would use this book with the whole class as a read aloud to talk about being descriptive. How do we know what the Gruffalo looks like without looking at the pictures?

It is a colorful and silly book. There are lot of rhyming words children can hear. Children may amaze how little mouse can scare all the animals, and live safely at the end. It may tell children should be calm down and try to think the solution when they meet the problems. So teachers can ask some questions and let children try to solve the problem after reading.

Making a lie is wrong on our daily life.A person often lie to others would annoy the other people, and can't make a closet friend.But sometimes we face a difficult situation, saying a lie maybe a clever deed.When a bad guy wants to hurt you, you lie to him maybe fool him and let you escape from him.

This book is fantasy fiction. I really enjoy this book because it's a story about a mouse who tricks every animal into being afraid of a gruffalo. The children love it because they get to see the mouse embark on a journey of tricking his fellow animal friends. I would like to read this book when teaching students about rhyme and repetition.

As part of the Reading Challenge over Christmas, I read The Gruffalo again.In reflection, I think Julia Donaldson's book teaches kids that 'might doesn't always make right'. It features short rhymes and has a repetitive structure that makes the book an engaging read for children. Also, the illustrations drawn by Axel Scheffler, are vibrant and make the story come alive!

After enjoying this piece of art with my kid now for quite some months, I got to say it is just perfect. I never get tired reading it, which is rare. The story is so cute and smart. The rhymes are so catchy, my 2 year old was able to speak along very quickly which is so much fun for both of us. If you have a kid, make yourself and the little one a gift and get this book!
